text: A young teacher (DARLA) chalks a lesson on a blackboard i sun-drenched Los Angeles classroom.
-- and we know from yesterday that the base of a triangle times half the height equals the area. A girl in the back row raises her hand.
Yes, Mia?

Lucy's asleep again. Darla puts down the chalk and comes up the aisle to where slight, fair-skinned girl in a thrift shop dress sleeps h down on her desk. The girl from the opening scene. LUCY SHERIDAN. Darla stands over her with obvious concern. Put a finger to her lips to quiet the giggles.
Let her sleep. She draws the shade. It drops a shadowbox on the sleeping girl. 2.

location: COUNSELING ROOM, DEPARTMENT OF CHILD SERVICES, LOS

text: A former gang member sitting with his wife and troubled e year-old son. The MARTINEZ FAMILY. A family in crisis. Sitting opposite is an LA County social worker. Twenties. Attractive but overworked. EMILY.
He would just go off, you know, start tearin' the place down. You didn't even know why he was doin' it half the time, you just got out of his way...
And what you learned from your father now Diego's learning from you...? It's painful for him to hear that. He loves his son, quit the streets for him. Overcome by emotion, he nods yes.
That really upsets you, doesn't it? He wipes his eyes on his tattooed arm.
Yeah. Cuz I mean I don't want him to be like me. The boy looks at his father, has never seen him cry befor
Outside the conference room, Emily musses the boy's hair.
A whole week without skipping school? Is that true? He smiles, nods. A glimpse of the boy he might have been.

That's the last time I make a bet with you. (to his parents) See you guys next week. The Martinez family heads down the hall, Diego lagging behind. Emily watches with guarded optimism, knowing thei chances. Then turns to the NEXT FAMILY, welcoming the
You cut your hair. It looks great.

The hurried opening and closing of files reveals PHOTOS o abused children. Bruises. Cuts. Broken bones. Emily trying to locate a single case amid the stacks and clutte her desk. An angry mother SCREAMING at her on the phone:

No one is trying to steal your child, they found bruises and cigarette burns -- Mrs Lynch, I read the medical report -- well, if you feel you need legal representation that's perfectly within your rights... A flurry of obscenities followed by a dial tone. Emily pu the phone down. Sighs wearily.
One less Christmas card for Emily. Her supervisor WAYNE, forties, gay, leaning in the doorwa
How many active cases you have?
Thirty-eight. He drops another file on her desk.
No, absolutely not, look at this, Wayne, look, I'm buried --

Sorry, Em, we all are. He walks off. Emily shoves the new file onto the shelf ab her desk. Looks at it guiltily. Takes it down again. Handwritten on the front: SHERIDAN, LUCY. She opens it. A school portrait of ten-year-old Lucy clip to the preliminary report. The sad face draws Emily in.
An old VOLVO WAGON skirts rush hour traffic on Wilshire. Faded red paint. Ski rack on the roof. An ancient bumpersticker says Educate. 4.
IPod jacked into the car stereo playing hip alternative MUSIC, Emily leans on an elbow as she drives, not crazy a L.A. but at ease with herself.
Emily's red Volvo wagon turns in the drive of a single-pe home she rents in a working-class neighborhood.

Cozy. Her haven. Light colors offset dark hardwood floors Emily comes in, stack of files under her arm. Tired. Long day. Drops the files in a chair. Sprinkles some food in a fish tank. Referees through the glass.

Don't fight. Hey, that's his. Turns on the tv. World news. Violence. People suffering. Turns it off. Puts on some quiet music. Hits play on her answering machine as she flops down barefoot on the sofa a magazine, peeling an orange, decompressing.
Hey, it's Suze, missed you at yoga the other day, give me a call. BEEP.
Hi, Em, Jackie, just checking in, hope you're good. BEEP. A charming male voice:

Exhausted, her career path questionable, her faith in mankind shaken, she resisted her tendency toward introspection and went to have a drink with her friend Doug. BEEP. Emily gives a tired sigh. Faint smile under it.
Noisy, trendy downtown bar. Professional type on a bar stool. Thirties. Handsome. DOUG. He laughs when he sees Emily. 5.
I am so in your head. She gives him a kiss. Sits down beside him.
Be honest. The whole psychology thing, it's just about scoring chicks, isn't it?
Regrettably, yes. They share a laugh. He gestures to the bartender for anot beer.
You know what freaks me out?
That you have a four-year degree and make seventeen grand a year after taxes?
I sit there talking to these families, you know, like I'm some expert. My family's a train wreck. I mean, I had this moment today where I realized I might be totally full of it.

Everybody's full of it. In the end you're a number to call for people who don't have anyone else. There's no way that's bad. Emily nods, appreciates that. Recognizes a girl going by the crowd. A friend from school. Well-dressed. Career- oriented. The track Emily might be on if she weren't a social worker.
Hey Becca...
Hey. So one of us is a major screwup, I can't remember if I was supposed to call you or the other way around...?
No, it's me, it's just been a crazy couple weeks. You remember Doug. 6.
Hi. (then to Emily) Listen, my ride's leaving, let's catch up soon, okay? Emily nods okay. The girl departs. Emily's beer arrives. Doug hands it to her.

So anyway, I've done some soul searching and I just want to say that if a full-on relationship feels like too much right now, I'd be willing to consider a purely physical one. Emily, sipping her beer, smiles.
Hey, you might actually enjoy yourself.
I'm sure I would, I just... Hard to explain. Doug saves her the trouble.
I know, I know, the job, you get home you don't have anything left. Emily nods yeah, leans in closer, the friendly banter giv way to a moment of real sincerity.
If it were anyone, it'd be you. They exchange a look then Doug clinks his glass against h And as they drink together after a long day, more than friends, less than lovers...

Emily in glasses, reading the Sheridan file on her bed. T preliminary report concerns her: "Socially withdrawn. Lac of appetite. Sleeping at school..." Her gaze returns to Lucy's photo. Sadly, under her breath
What are they doing to you? 7.
A dark, rundown family home on a once-prosperous cul de s Emily pulls up. Gets out. Checks that she has the right address. Halfway up the walk something stops her dead in

staring at her through one of the lacy white curtains upstairs. Ghostly pale. Gone as soon as she sees it. Emil stands frozen for a moment. Walks on. She reaches to knock on the door and it opens abruptly, t security chain snapping taut. A woman's voice growls at h from the darkness inside:
What?
Emily Jennings. Child Services? We spoke on the phone...? Peering through the crack is the pallid, bony face from t upstairs window. Lucy's mother. MARGARET SHERIDAN.
You said the seventeenth.
Today is the seventeenth.
Is not.
I'm sorry, but it is.
Friday was the thirteenth. Emily, rather amazed at the conversation she's having, ta a newspaper from her bag. Indicates the date.

Friday was the fourteenth, that makes today the seventeenth. Monday the seventeenth. The date of our appointment. The door closes in Emily's face. What the hell? Then we hear the chain unlock. It opens again. 8. And we get our first good look at Lucy's mother. Gaunt. Pale. Dark rings under her eyes. She steps aside, not welcoming Emily in, merely allowing her to enter.

It's dark, the curtains drawn. Margaret twitches one open begrudging courtesy. The house is tidy but sad, steeped i kind of puritanical gloom. Lucy peers down through the upstairs banister, anxious, unsure what's going on. Emily sees her, smiles.
Come down, I'd like to meet you. Lucy hesitates, sensing her mother's disapproval. Comes slowly down the stairs. Emily shakes her hand.
My name's Emily. What's yours?
Lucy.
Pretty name. Pretty girl. Lucy turns shyly away.
Is there somewhere we can talk? Margaret sighs and heads down the hall.
Emily, file in hand, trying to project professionalism in arm chair that tilts to one side. Margaret and Lucy sitti opposite on the sofa.
When do you expect your husband back? Margaret shrugs.
Because we've found it's more beneficial if the whole family participates.
Well he's not home so... Shrugs again. 9.
Do you have any way of contacting him?
Not if I don't know where he is. Just then we hear a POWER TOOL go on in the basement. Emi sensing the lie, indicates the floor.
Is that...? Margaret averts her eyes.
Would you ask him to join us?
He doesn't have anything to say.
Would you ask him? Margaret weighs Emily's resolve, gives Lucy a cautionary glance then exits. We hear her open a door and holler int the basement over the noise of the power tool.
Edward! EDWARD! The power tool stops.
That lady's here. From the state. She wants to talk to you. We hear an angry unintelligible reply.
I already told her, she wants to anyway. We hear the power tool get thrown aside. FOOTSTEPS poundi up the cellar stairs. Emily's and Lucy's faces reflect th same simple fear. Their eyes meet.
It'll be okay. Lucy not so sure. The FOOTSTEPS are upon them. EDWARD SHERIDAN makes his entrance. A menacing man with a gaunt face and dark deep-set eyes. Emily holds out her hand. 10.

Hi, I'm Emily -- Edward forgoes the handshake, his contempt obvious. Sits beside Lucy on the sofa. Margaret sits on the other side. Lucy tenses, trapped between them. Emily speaks with kindness and composure. Hostile encounters part of the jo

I'm here today because Lucy's school is concerned about changes they're seeing in her academic performance. The kinds of changes they're seeing are often associated with family problems. Edward leans over and whispers something caustic in Margaret's ear.
Eddie says we don't have family problems.

That's just it, many times a family won't even know they're having problems until it's too late. That's where we come in. We help families communicate and learn healthier ways of resolving conflict. Edward whispers again in Margaret's ear.
Eddie says we don't need your help.
Mr Sheridan, is there some reason you won't speak to me directly? Edward just stares at her.
Is there some reason why your husband won't speak to me directly? Margaret nods, gives Edward a look as though for permissi

Eddie doesn't like speakin' out of anger. Emily does well to hide her fear. Refusing to be intimidated, she engages Edward's stare. A battle of will But his gaze has a murderous intensity she can't match. S looks down, shuffling papers. Battle lost. 11.
Emily follows Wayne along a row of cubicles after hours. He's dropping files on desks. The new cases never stop.
No laws against being weird, Em. Send it over to CMC, we'll do a follow-up in a month.
I didn't say weird, I said scary. The guy sat there the entire time staring at me, the mother is like his emotional slave. Wayne pauses in mock bewilderment.
Wait, did you just fly to New York and meet my parents?
Wayne, this girl's in trouble. I can feel it. Beneath Wayne's humor, a sober, hard-learned practicality
Wanna know what I can feel? The lawsuit we're gonna get hit with if we violate her parents' rights without any evidence they've done something wrong.
Every time I talk to you you sound more like a lawyer, you know that?
Yeah, well, maybe because every time I make an emotional decision I get called by one. I'm sorry, you're gonna have to let this one go.

You put these files in front of me and you ask me to tell you what's going on. Well, I'm telling you, there's something going on and it's not something good. I've done my job, I've told you, what you do with it is yours. She walks off. Wayne alone after hours with his conscienc 12.

The elevator doors open with a DING and Edward and Margar Sheridan step out in their Sunday best. Benevolent faces. Lucy between them, ribbon in her hair, brand new dress, appearing coached as she eats an ice cream cone. Emily, disgusted by the charade, trades looks with the parents as they go past.
Gazing fondly at Lucy, Edward directs his comments at Way who sits opposite the family with Emily.

They really are God's miracles. Day she was born was the happiest day of our lives. We're not perfect parents, we know that, but we figure if you let `em know how much you love `em a lot of the other stuff takes care of itself. Wayne nods his agreement. Edward puts his arm around Lucy for effect. Her eyes go to Emily. A silent plea for help.
Tell me, Mr Sheridan, since you've suddenly acquired the power of speech, doesn't it concern you a little that Lucy's grades have gone from A's to D's in three months?
Course it does, she's our daughter. With a glance Wayne cautions Emily about her tone of voic
So you have no idea why she's falling asleep at school every day? Why she's not able to sleep at home? Edward looks at Margaret, then Emily, affects bewildermen
Bad dreams?
Emily and Wayne in private conversation. She's pissed off The Sheridan family in the other room, preparing to leave 13.
He's gonna be having bad dreams when he gets hit with child endangerment. (off Wayne's reluctance) Don't tell me you're buying this daddy's little girl routine?
So they're overcompensating a little.
A little? Let me talk to her. Alone. She wants to talk.
Five minutes. Talk to them about how much they love kids. She goes out the door.
Emily walks with Lucy, looking for a way in.

I knew someone at school named Lucy, she was a writer. Do you ever write? I do sometimes, it helps me sort out how I'm feeling. Lucy doesn't take the bait. She stops for a drink at a wa fountain. Emily bends for a sip after. Misfires. As she wipes her face, embarrassed:
Okay, I just shot like a gallon of water up my nose. So much for establishing trust. Lucy smiles, for the first time. It's the opening Emily w looking for. Maintaining that precious eye contact,
What's happening to you? I can help. Let me help. Lucy looks away, eyes brimming with tears. 14.
What is it, sweetheart?
They hate me. She lowers her head in shame, tears rolling down.
I'm sure they don't hate you.
They do. I hear them. They go in the cellar and talk.
What do they talk about?
Sending me to hell. Emily's mouth falls open.
You've heard them say that? Lucy nods. As Emily registers this in quiet horror...
A tape recorder is running. Emily and Wayne alone with Lu She's hesitant to speak, naturally distrustful.
It's okay. You can tell him. He's on our side.

Did you hear your parents say they were going to hurt you? Nobody sees what Lucy sees at this moment. Edward glaring at her through the window. Lucy looks at Wayne, shakes he head. Wayne looks at Emily, case closed.
Emily watches in agony as the Sheridan family steps into elevator. Parent on each side, Lucy gives her one last pleading look then the elevator doors close and she's gon 15.
Emily and Wayne in the heat of an argument.
She doesn't trust anybody. You think I made it up?

I think you'd do just about anything you had to do to help a child you thought was at risk. Here are the facts, Emily. They haven't laid a finger on her that we can tell. And we have no proof they intend to. Meanwhile on your desk right now are thirty-plus cases of actionable abuse. What about those?
I'm not giving up on her, Wayne.
Yes, you are, you're leaving this alone. A look that says he means it.
I hope you can live with a dead child on your conscience.

That's a little unfair, don't you think? I care about these kids as much as you do, but we can't go around yanking them out of their homes on a hunch. Parents, even bad ones, have rights, that's how the laws of this great land are written. Emily gives a resigned nod, backing away from him, from t job, all of it.
So that's it? We let kids get killed until they rewrite the goddamn laws? She exits before he can answer, doesn't want to hear it.
Detective MIKE BARRON. Veteran of the force. Man of quiet faith. 16. A well-built silver-haired family man who played fullback Brigham Young. He's doing paperwork. Smiles warmly as Emi enters.
Was just thinking about you, got a nice letter from Sandy Hutchinson... She drops Lucy's file on his desk. Whatever Barron was go to say is no longer relevant. Soberly, after a pause:
Well, it's sitting in front of me which means our good friend Wayne thinks it fails to meet the criteria for child endangerment and has told you in no uncertain terms to leave it alone...?
Surprise, surprise. She starts to open the file. Barron stops her.
I can't, Emily. I'm sorry.
Mike, I'm desperate here. Tense beat. The need for privacy now apparent, Barron get up and closes his door. Sits down at his desk again.
You know how dear to my heart the work you do is, but the department doesn't pay me to stakeout potential child abusers. Last time almost cost me my job.
This girl heard her parents say they're going to send her to hell.
Sickening as that is, you're a part of the system that handles those situations, I'm not.
The system is broken.
Maybe you just need to let it work. 17.
What? Jesus, I feel like I'm talking to Wayne. You don't want to get involved, fine, but don't bullshit me, I'm running out of people I respect.
Okay. No bullshit. Give me evidence of a crime, I'll be all over it. Till then there's nothing I can do.

The blade of a circular saw SCREAMS through a pinewood bo spitting sawdust... A ten-pound hammer CRUSHES the head of a nail, sinking it CRUSHES another, CRUSHES another, the speed of the handiw conveying its urgency...
Lucy peering into the basement through an air vent in the floor, vertical bands of light on her face. Edward hammer down below. He steps aside and we see what he's making...
Sensing Lucy's stare, he glances up over his shoulder. An Lucy ducks out of sight, breath held.
Children waiting for the bus after school. Talking, laughing. Lucy stands apart, tired and solemn. The bus pulls up to the curb. As she goes to get on:
Lucy. She turns. Emily behind her.
I just wanted you to know I haven't forgotten about you. I'm doing everything I can. Lucy hugs her, clinging for a moment.
If I disappear will you come look for me? 18.
You're not going to disappear.
If I do? Emily holds her gaze, seeing the fear. Backing away, Lucy indicates the bus.
I have to go. They get mad when I miss the bus. Lucy turns to go. Emily watches. Helpless.
Lucy, wait... Takes her cell phone from her bag. Puts her number on spe dial.
If anything happens, call me, okay? Just press this. Don't let your parents know you have it. Tucks the cell phone in Lucy's coat pocket.
I'm gonna get you out of there, I promise. Lucy boards the bus. Waves to Emily from a back window as drives away. Emily waves back, heart in her throat. Might be the last time she sees her alive.
A sleepless night finds Emily slouched on her sofa, leavi
Hey, this is Doug, here it comes - BEEP.

It's me, thought you might be up, um, anyway, call if you get this. Hangs up. Clicks on the tv remote. Channel-surfs. World news. Cooking show. Home shopping network. 19. Hip-hop music video. Watches it for a moment. Gangster wi a mic. Scantily-clad girls shaking their asses. The phone RINGS. Emily mutes the tv, picks up.
Too late, I met someone else... A child's whisper.
Emily...?
(concerned but calm) Lucy? Are you okay?
I'm scared...
Why? Why are you scared, honey?
They're waiting to get me, I can hear them... I'm sorry...
Why are you sorry?
I'm falling asleep...
Okay, listen, I want you to go over and open the window. Can you do that? Lucy...?
(softly; drifting off) I'm sooorry...
Lucy, no, wake up!
The cell phone lying on the bed at Lucy's fingertips.
Lucy...?! 20. The illuminated screen casts an eerie glow on her SLEEPIN FACE.
Emily drops the phone. Moment of panic. Then a decision. Throws a coat on over her bed clothes. Grabs the phone again, dials a number in desperation.
Mike, it's Emily, listen, that girl I told you about, I think she's in trouble - - yeah, I know what you said, but -- Mike, you're not listening --
Emily fumbles with her keys. Gets the right one in the do Opens it. Jumps in. Starts the engine. Peels off down the road.

The cell phone turns itself off, plunging the room into t darkness. In BLACK, we hear FOOTSTEPS coming up the stairs. Down th hall. Stopping at the door. The knob turning. The click o the latch. The door opening. A shaft of light. Edward and Margaret peering in with frenzied anticipation: Lucy is asleep. The time has come.
Emily red-lines the tachometer, doing ninety down the freeway.

Slowly, quietly, Edward descends the stairs with Lucy asl in his arms. Margaret in front of him, moving in tandem, holding a roll of duct tape. They reach the bottom. Margaret rushes ahead into the kitchen.

Edward carries Lucy toward the OLD GAS OVEN where Margare waits, holding open the door. 21. Delicately, cradling her head, Edward puts Lucy into the without waking her. But as he lifts the door, one of the metal hinges CREAKS. Lucy jolts awake with a SCREAM. Kicks open the door befor Edward can shut it. With animal terror she thrashes her w out onto the linoleum floor. Margaret throws a piece of d tape over her mouth, silencing her screams as Edward wres her back into the oven. But she kicks open the door again and the frantic struggle continues as...
Emily's car lurches to a stop out front. As she jumps out Barron's pickup arrives. He joins her, a reluctant accomplice.
What are we doing here?
Saving her life! She goes up the walkway. Barron lagging a few steps behin eyeing the darkened house.
They're asleep.
They're not asleep. Emily hears something inside the house.
Did you hear that?
I didn't hear anything. Emily, trusting her gut, starts pounding on the door.
Leave her alone!

Hearing Emily, Edward and Margaret intensify their effort jamming Lucy's legs inside the oven. The duct tape peels her mouth in the struggle and before the oven door slams she belts out one last desperate SCREAM. 22.
Clearly audible outside, it makes Barron jump.
Did you hear that?! Barron pounds his big fist on the door.
Police, open up!
Break it down! Barron rams his shoulder against the door, but it holds solid.
We see Lucy's screaming face through the oven window as Margaret cranks the temperature dial as high as it will g

From inside we see Edward and Margaret peering in as Lucy claws at the glass with her fingernails. Coughing as the fills the oven with a low hiss. We hear it ignite beneath her with a faint poof. The first shimmering waves of heat rising up, singeing her hair.
Emily, hysterical, knowing they're too late:
The front door comes crashing down, kicked off its hinges Barron. Emily and he race in.
They take off toward the kitchen at the end of the hall.
Emily and Barron rush in. Emily sees Lucy trapped inside oven. The sleeve of her pajamas catching fire. 23.

Oh my God... Edward tries to fend Barron off. It's a mistake. Barron unleashes a devastating blow that sends him recoiling int the fridge so hard the back of his head leaves a visible in the door. Emily shoves Margaret aside and throws open the oven. Pul Lucy out onto the kitchen floor, swatting out her burning pajamas with a dish towel. Margaret grabs a steak knife and rushes at Emily, but Bar has her covered. Backhands Margaret so hard it spins her around fully before dropping her to the floor.

The hell's the matter with you people?! Pajamas scorched, wild with terror, Lucy cries in great heaving sobs in Emily's arms. Reduced to tears herself, Emily keeps saying the same thing over and over.

I gotcha... I gotcha... I gotcha... Shielding her from the sight of her parents: Margaret sprawled on the linoleum weeping. Edward slouched against the fridge, blood pouring down his shirt, his broken jaw hanging open like a man thinking wow.

Edward and Margaret holding hands at the defendant's tabl remorseless and defiant in their Sunday best. Among the m spectators we find Emily and Mike Barron. The STATE PROSECUTOR and PUBLIC DEFENDER addressing the JUDGE.
Prosecution asks that you disallow an insanity defense. This was an act committed with premeditation, malice
Your honor, the egregiousness of the crime makes the competency question all the more relevant.
Yes. I hereby order the defendants undergo psychiatric evaluation to determine their mental fitness for trial. 24. Emily rolls her eyes at Barron, some justice system.
Barron walks Emily to her car. She's outraged.
Steal a pizza, San Quentin, try killing your kid, Freudian dream analysis.
Well, you're gonna hate me for saying this, but my money's on crazy.
Did they or did they not know what they were doing? That's the legal standard. They knew, they knew damn well!
It's not that simple sometimes.
(stops on a dime) Meaning what exactly? Barron hesitates. He's crossing the line by telling her this.
When we brought them in that night they told Captain Lister... They think she's evil, some kind of demon spirit, minion of the devil or something.
Oh, that's great - what is this, late- night cable?
No, but that might be the world they're living in.
Lucy in a hospital bed, dressings on her hand. Emily's friend Doug sitting bedside. Child psychologist.
-- and what's the most important thing we talked about that you have to remember? 25.
It's not my fault what happened.
That's right and you know what? It's not. Lucy nods, not entirely convinced. Doug gives her a pat, crosses to the exit. At the door he runs into Emily. Shak his head, awed at what she did.
That is some seriously proactive social work happenin' there. You all right?
Yeah, I'm okay. How's she doing?
Typical reaction, blames herself. We'll get there. I'm gonna put her in a group setting, see if I can get her to open up.
Group therapy for kids, what's that say about the world? He nods - no kidding, heads off. Emily comes over and sit on Lucy's bed. Strokes her hair.
Good news. You get to leave here tomorrow.
Doug said I might have to go to a state home.
Only for a few days, till we find a better place.
Why can't I live with you?
Oh, sweetheart. That would never be allowed.
Why? 26.
It's complicated, there's a whole process, I'm not even a foster parent... Lucy gives a sad nod. Emily touches her arm.
I'm sorry.
No frills, purely functional housing. Emily comes up the steps with Lucy and knocks. The COORDINATOR answers. A ki but beleagured-looking woman of fifty, who is surprised t see them.
They were supposed to call you. We don't have any rooms.
Nothing?
There was a mixup with the dates. Sorry. Emily rolls her eyes. Lucy standing there holding a suitcase.

Through the windshield Lucy watches Emily on a pay phone outside a convenience store. Her back is to us but you ca see she's arguing with someone, scratching addresses off typed list with a ballpoint.
Emily gets in and starts the car, putting on a smile.
Hey, are you hungry? Let's get some lunch. What kind of food do you like?
There's nowhere for me to go is there? Heartbreaking. Emily can't lie. She turns off the engine and leans back with a sigh. Lucy's silence is a plea for rescue. 27.
I can't, Lucy, it wouldn't work, I live in this tiny house, I... I'm sorry, I'm not mom material...
You don't have to be my mom. Just my friend. A ten-year-old girl stranded at a convenience store, suit in her lap. Emily stares out the windshield, wrestling wi her conscience.
At a round table, Emily addresses the CHILD WELFARE PANEL six grave-faced administrators. Wayne is here, offering support.

I know what it feels like to be that age and be unwanted. It's terrifying. She needs to be with someone she trusts; she trusts me. So much of our time is spent negotiating red tape, I think if we just look at the situation - this one situation, this one child - it's clear what's best for her. The head of the panel is a bloated bureaucrat in a polka blouse (NANCY).
This is highly irregular and I'll tell you right now it makes me very uncomfortable. But since, Wayne, you've spoken so persuasively on Miss Jennings's behalf...
Emily comes out and nods yes to Lucy who waits with a guardian. As they hug:
...I'm going to go against my better judgement and approve this petition for temporary custody.
Emily walks Lucy through the house, showing her around, tidying things self-consciously. 28.
I like to think of it as a glass-half- full situation. Kitchen. Bathroom. Fish. And here, is your room...
They stop in the doorway. A small office in which Emily h made space for a bureau and a bed. Professional books and backup case files pushed aside on a shelf.
Be okay? Lucy nods yes.
Where's your family?
My family... well, I've met my dad twice and my mom's not a part of my life anymore.
Why?

(choosing her words) Sometimes people have kids and then decide they don't want to be parents. Beneath the measured tone Emily's pain is revealed, raw a untouchable, her entire life a rebellion against it. She opens Lucy's suitcase on the bed. Pauses, remembering something.
I'm glad you're here. Lucy comes over to help unpack the clothes.
Lucy in bed, sipping a cup of tea as Emily brushes her ha
What's this?
Chamomile, when I get stressed out it helps me sleep. 29. Lucy nods that it's good. Emily brushes her hair. A natur bond between them.
None of this ever should have happened, if I could make it go away I would.
You did. Nice moment for Emily. A rare triumph. She tucks Lucy in. Turns off the bedside light.
I'm right down the hall if you need me. Lucy settles. Emily pauses at the door, looks back at the lost child she's taken in, then closes the door halfway.
Dark, abandoned. Emily's Volvo pulls up.

She eyes the house. It haunts her, the memory of what happened. A SUDDEN KNOCK on the window makes her jump out of her se The guy there gestures a friendly sorry, didn't mean to s you. White shirt and tie. A COURT CLERK.
Emily signs a form as he unlocks the door, letting her in
I have to grab some of her things, might take me a minute.
I trust ya, Em, make sure you lock it on the way out.

Emily closes the door, glances around the dark interior. Through a window she sees the Court Clerk drive off. She' alone. It's quiet, eerily still. She goes up the stairway. Slows, noticing something on th
A FAINT SQUARE where a picture once was hung, the wallpap half tone darker underneath. More SQUARES farther up. A f nails still sticking out.
Tattered lace curtains sway in a draft beside a bed with moth-eaten coverlet. Emily packs Lucy's spare clothes int dufflebag. Zips it and walks out.
Exiting Lucy's room, she notes the door to Edward and Margaret's bedroom, at the far end of the hall, is slight AJAR. Succumbs to a natural curiosity.

The door pushes open, Emily peering in. A sad little mast bedroom with old floral printed wallpaper and water stain the ceiling. She explores the room, inspecting various personal items aftershave, glasses, hair brush - looking for clues to th madness. An ALARM CLOCK with a cracked crystal face. She picks it and it GOES OFF in her hand. Gives her a scare. She puts down. Sees something out the bedroom window. Steps closer Parts the curtains. In the backyard, by the garden shed, a long rectangular h has been dug. A SHALLOW GRAVE filling with leaves. Edward handiwork. Emily's seen enough, heads for the door. But slows, noticing something odd as she comes back aroun the bed -
in the wooden floor, hidden under a long runner rug. Emil peels back the rug and finds -

in the floorboards leading toward the door. Something - t old oak bureau perhaps? - has been dragged repeatedly acr the room. Emily comes over and looks behind the door and sees, on t back of it, something even more bizarre -

screwed hastily, crookedly, into the wood. She closes the door. Slides-to the big heavy bolts - CLUNK. CLUNK. Pauses. Looks again at the bureau. Slides it in front of the door, a wheelless caster bracket leaving another long scratch in the hardwood. And it's clear at this point wha the deadbolts and bureau add up to -

Emily stares at it. Looks over at Edward and Margaret's b imagining them here behind this door. Slides the bureau aside. Opens the deadbolts. And as the door swings open s is looking straight down the hall at
Emily stares, bewildered.
ABUSED CHILDREN aged eight to thirteen sit in a circle of folding chairs. Lucy among them. Diego. Doug facilitating
Sometimes when our parents aren't getting along it's better if they don't see each other for a while, that's what a `restraining order' does...

Emily looks in, waiting with other parents. Lucy sees her the window and sneaks her a little wave. Emily smiles and holds up a hand that says, hi, hon. It's clear from these gestures how close they've gotten.
Emily and Doug walk together after session. Lucy talking other kids her age by the elevator.
She's starting to come out of her shell. It's good, I just wish I thought it was me making the difference. Emily accepts the compliment. 32.
I went by the house. I think her mom and dad were barricading themselves in their room at night. How sick is that?
Hatred and fear are part of the same pathology - oh, but I forgot, you don't think they're crazy.
I'm coming around. As they part ways...
Emily pulls up in front of Lucy's school. Big moment for Lucy. New clothes. New haircut. New life.
Okay? Lucy nods, apprehensive, but she's ready to face it. Emil hugs her.
This is your new beginning. Lucy gets out. Pauses on the sidewalk.
I love you, Emily. Emily, touched, smiles.
I love you, too. Lucy goes up the walk. Emily watches her safely into the building.
Emily draws grim looks as she crosses the common area. A pall hanging over the entire department. The first person she walks past says:
Wayne's looking for you. The second person: 33.
Wayne wants to --

Got it. She comes past Wayne's office. Empty. A coworker points over toward Emily's cubicle - he's there. She goes over. Wayne's inside, grave-faced, looking for a file. He finds on the shelf. A photo of eight-year-old DIEGO clipped ins the cover. The boy we met earlier.
What's up with Diego? Wayne hesitates, wanting to spare her the bad news.
Why don't we talk in my office.
Tell me what's going on.
We don't know why yet, but... he killed his mother and father last night. Emily stands there, jaw on the floor.

A police perimeter around a small house in a tough low-in neighborhood. Cops and crime scene investigators on the scene. Local news media broadcasting live. A couple of ne choppers hovering overhead. Emily pulls up, jumps out of her car. Mike Barron waves o the uniformed officer who moves to intercept her as she c up the walkway to the house.
What happened?
Sure you want to see this? With an uncertain nod she follows him inside.
Emily and Mike Barron come along the uncarpeted hallway. 34.
Gets a tire iron from the garage, comes back inside, locks all the doors and windows, kills them in their sleep... The master bedroom. A bloodbath.
Had to use dental records to identify the bodies. Emily looks around, aghast.
An eight-year-old did this? There's no way.

I was there when they brought him in. Took three guys my size to subdue him. Kid was climbing the walls. Barron turns to the window and - WHAM! - AN ATTACK DOG HI THE GLASS RIGHT IN FRONT OF HIS FACE. Barron recoils with yelp. Then, embarrassed, eyes the TRIO OF BATTLE-SCARRED BULLS prowling the chainlink-fenced backyard.
Just your average American family.
Emily and Barron come down the steps.
Where is he now?
Juvie lockup. And, no, I'm not taking you to see him.
You want to know what happened?
I know what happened.
I don't. I need to talk to him. Mike, please, I care about this kid. 35.
Diego Martinez sitting alone in a holding cell. Confused. Scared. He sees Emily approaching and immediately breaks down.
Diego... Emily tells the cop at the cell door:
Let me in. He won't hurt me. The cop looks at Mike Barron who nods it's okay. The cop opens the cell. Emily enters. Diego looks up at her, shuddering with emotion:
Are they dead? Emily, gutted, nods yes. Diego buries his face in Emily's stomach and sobs.
What happened? Tell me what happened.
I killed my mum and dad... Emily, devastated, trades looks with Barron through the b
Doug tenderly consoles Emily. Has his arms around her. They're leaning against the railing, wind on their faces.
Every family you sit down with every day of every week is a family in crisis. Those are your odds. That's the job you do. Trying to beat them. Wipes away her tears. The hair from her face.
You're one person, Em. You can't save the world.

I know somebody you did save. 36. Lucy on the beach below, walking barefoot at water's edge hem of her dress in her hands. Emily watches her and, finding solace in it, leans into Doug's embrace and close her eyes.
The plaintive cries of seagulls overhead as Emily and Luc walk along the surf at sundown, Emily barefoot now as wel
You okay? Emily nods, putting on a brave face to spare Lucy.
It's just work. Don't worry. Lucy nods okay. They walk on in silence for a moment.
Why do you do it if it makes you sad?

My job? I don't know, I guess... I guess maybe I want to believe families can work, so I can have my own someday, I don't know - does that make sense? Lucy nods, takes her hand. They walk off up the beach together.
Emily, days later, dressed for work, halves an omelet wit spatula and slides the halves onto two plates.
(calls to other room) Breakfast. There's no answer. Emily goes to get her.
Stops in the doorway.
Honey, breakfa-- Sees Lucy hide something under her pillow. Emily comes ov brow arched, playful. 37.

Come on, let me see... Lucy guiltily eyes the floor. Emily lifts the pillow. Underneath it is a photograph. EMILY, AS A YOUNG GIRL, WITH HER MOTHER. She looks at Lucy, then at the filing cabinet from which was taken. More surprised than upset.
You went through my things?
I'm sorry... I wanted to know what happened to you. Disarming sincerity. Emily's gaze falls to the photo. Qui moment. She sits down on the bed with it.

Is that your mom? Emily nods, lost in the image. It's a photo that captures her entire childhood. Emily and her mother sitting on the steps of a house, together but apart, like a lost child t sat down next to a pretty stranger who hasn't yet noticed her. Emily's ten-year-old face shows the quiet sadness of the disconnect. Reminds you of a child from her caseload.
She used to just leave, she'd just...

...and I never knew when she was coming back, or if she was... I used to think it was my fault and I would try so hard when she got home to be good, do everything I could think of, so she'd think I was `special' and stay next time or take me with her, but... it didn't matter, she'd always go away again, that's how it was. Emily fights her emotions and, practiced at the task, win Lucy sits beside her on the bed. Understands her deeply. Linked by their pasts.
Where was your dad?
Gone, he left before I was born. First time I met him I was like thirteen. 38.
What'd you say to him?

Oh, I had all these things I was gonna say. Angry things I'd thought of and kind of memorized. And um.... And then I met him and I wasn't angry, I was just sad and I told him... (pauses, raw emotion) I said, I love you, even if you don't love me. Emily smiles a pained smile and then buries the memory. Lucy, a portrait of contrition:
Are you mad at me?
No... No, I'm not mad at you. (puts her arm around her) But I need you not to do that again, okay? Go through my private things without asking? Lucy nods okay. Emily moves on, with a loving touch:

Omelet's getting cold. Better hurry. Lucy exits. Emily eyes the photo a moment longer then sta and puts it away in the filing cabinet. She pauses, feeli exposed, and turns the little key to lock the drawers.
Emily stops at her cubicle, registering a surprise. Wayne handing her case files to three COWORKERS. Awkward moment for everyone.
I need another set of eyes to go over them, make sure we haven't missed anything else.
You mean, to make sure I haven't missed anything else? 39.

It's just a legal thing. You'll have them back tomorrow. They exit. She goes in and stares at the BARE SHELF above her desk. Her caseload gone. More than an insult. Everything she cares about. A pink phone message on her keyboard. She picks it up: Mi Barron called. Important.
Newspaper headline: "INSANITY DEFENSE FOR GLENDALE COUPLE MUGSHOTS of Edward and Margaret below. The morning editio folded on a table between Barron and Emily. They're drink coffee.
You watch, six months, their lawyer will hire some expert to say they're rehabbed and they'll sue for custody when they get out.
She's not going back there, I'll take her out of state before I let them near her again.
I didn't hear you say that. Emily knows she's misspoken, but lets it stand.
You wanted to talk about something? Barron nods, sips his coffee, a bit uncomfortable.
We pulled the Martinezes' phone records. They got a call that night before the murders.
From who?
Emily, the call came from your house.
Look, I'm not accusing you of anything, I just need to know what was said.
That's impossible. I might have called the week before...?
I'm talking to you as a friend here, you know that, right?
Did you not hear me? I'm telling you, Mike, as a friend, I did not call that family.

Then who did? Go find the guy who broke in and just happened to dial the number of a kid whose case you handle. Emily starts to say something, but stops as a confounding realization comes to her. And then to Barron.
Lucy sits on the sofa studying a photo of Diego. Emily si beside her, her advocate. Barron opposite.
He's in my group... (puts down photo) ...why, did something happen? Emily nods yes. Barron, gently, mindful of Lucy's age:
We're trying to figure out why. He got a call Thursday night from this number. I'm just wondering if he might have said anything...
It wasn't me.
You didn't call him? Lucy shakes her head. Barron nods okay, then, speaking to her as a father might his own daughter: 41.
Lucy, it's hard sometimes to tell the truth, but I know you will because you're a good little girl.
I am telling the truth.
My backup files are in your room. Diego's is in there. Maybe you got curious and went through some, dialed a number?
It wasn't me, I swear. Complete innocence. Emily nods okay, wanting to believe, remembering the stolen photograph.
The call was at 2 am, are you ever up that late?
I didn't call him.
Are you ever up that late?
Mike, she said no. Maybe someone made a mistake. Barron reads Emily's posture and disengages, stands to go
Yeah, maybe so. Night, Lucy.
Exiting, Barron tells Emily as gently as possible:
She's lying. And goes down the steps. Emily closes the door. Turns around and there's Lucy. Uncomfortably close.
Do you believe me? 42.
I believe you. Lucy hugs her and Emily hugs her back, but she's still thinking about what Barron said.

A PHOTO of Emily and Diego tacked to the corkboard panel beside her desk. Emily sits contemplating it. Her gaze go from the photo to the BARE SHELF above her desk. Her caseload is still missing. This is bullshit.
Emily walks in, power pose.
Give me back my cases or fire me. Right now. Wayne, caught unprepared, eating a doughnut.
Caseload restored, Emily is multi-tasking, opening mail, sorting backlogged paperwork, talking on the phone:

I don't care if it's a hairline fracture, he broke her arm, I don't want him back in that house. He what? He found Christ? When? That recently? Uh huh. Well he should have found Him sooner. Hangs up. Doug leans in the doorway, drops a manila envel in her in-box. And a computer printout.
What's up?
Copy of the Sheridans' psych evals for the file. And the cognitive profile Lucy did for me the other day.
(re: Lucy's profile) How's it look?
Normal. 43. But his tone suggests otherwise.
Do I have to beg or are you gonna tell me what's going on?
You have to beg.
Coming from an environment like that, testing this normal is a bit abnormal, if that makes any sense.
She's `abnormally normal'?
I think she faked it, gave the answers she thought she should.
Why would she do that?
She's ashamed of who she is. Ashamed of how she feels. Afraid nobody would want her if they saw the real her. (off Emily's reaction) It's no big deal, it just means I might have to push her a little.
No, I know, I just... The Martinezes' got a call Thursday night. From my house.
Did you ask her about it?
She said she didn't. Mike thinks she's lying.
What do you think?
I don't know what to think.
Hmm. Bring her in after work, I'll do a one-on-one. I wanted to talk to her about this anyway. 44. He departs. Emily, alone in her cubicle, scans the test results with growing concern.
Diego eating macaroni and cheese from a jailhouse tray. Emily sets a folded blanket on the bed as she sits down t talk to him.
Got you an extra in case it gets cold. Diego nods without looking up.
I need to ask you something... about the night it happened... did you get a call, really late? Diego stops eating. Stares at his food. Shakes his head n warily, like someone might be listening.
You didn't? He shakes his head no. Still staring at his food.
Diego, I know you did, they called from my house. Diego puts down his fork, his fear obvious now, his breat quick and shallow.
What's the matter? What's scaring you? He looks at Emily, terrified, starts HYPERVENTILATING.
Oh God... Emily tries to calm the panicked boy as he gasps for air, horrible WHEEZING sound in his throat.
It's okay... slow breaths... you'll be okay... (yelling down hall) Can somebody help us down here?! 45.
A little two-bed infirmary with unpainted cinder block wa Diego in bed on an IV drip. Emily talking to a NURSE by t check-in desk.
He asked to see you before you left. Emily comes over to Diego's bed. He holds her gaze in silence, a secret he's afraid to tell. Emily speaks at a whisper, as if to make the truth less frightening:
Who called you? Was it Lucy? Diego's PULSE ACCELERATES on the EKG monitor. He gives a trembling nod.
Did she say something to you? Something that scared you? Diego replies in Spanish, barely discernible, his throat
El dijo...
`El' dijo? What do you mean, `He said'? Diego looks at her, confused, terrified. His RACING PULSE jagged green line above the bed.
Era un hombre. A chill goes through Emily.
It was a man? Diego gives another trembling nod. Emily beside him, baff and a bit scared.

After hours, the office is empty, half lit and eerily sti Emily is photocopying at a work station, haunted by what Diego said, the harsh upward light accentuating her tense features. 46. The CYCLICAL SQUEAKING NOISE we hear is Lucy, in Emily's cubicle in the b.g., turning herself in circles on the of chair. Something very creepy about the disappearance and reappearance of that pale watchful face. Finished, Emily walks back to her cubicle, thrown by the sight of Lucy spinning in the chair, walking head-on into that eerie intermittent gaze.
Do...
you...
like...
working...
here? Emily, unnerved, enters the cubicle.
Well, photocopying isn't much fun. Lucy stops turning, stares at her, sensing something.
What...? Lucy just stares. Doug appears in the doorway.
Knock, knock. Sorry I'm late, guys.
Ready, kiddo? Lucy nods and gets up from the chair.
Go ahead down, I'll be right there. Lucy heads down the hall to the conference room.
You all right?

This is weird. Diego said it was Lucy that called, but he called her a he, he said it was a man. 47. His face - what? Emily nods yes. Doug's brow arches then furrows. He turns and heads down the hall.
Doug sits opposite Lucy at the table, keeps it easygoing despite what he's just been told.
So how's school?
Fine.
Any of your classmates giving you a hard time?
No, they've been nice.
Sleeping okay?
That's not really what you want to talk about, is it, Doug? Awkward pause. Awkward smile.
You got me. Opens his file. Takes out her cognitive assessment profil Lays it flat on the table.

Question 16a, are you afraid of the dark? You answered `no'. Question 16b, are you afraid of being alone? `No'. 16c, are afraid of your parents? `No'. You answered `no' to everything in that section. I think some of those should have been yesses. Everybody is afraid of something. Working through our fears, conquering them, is how we get better. So I want you to tell me... What scares you? Lucy steeples her fingers and rests her chin on top, rega Doug with a look of frank appraisal. It is the face of a child, but behind those eyes there is a keen intelligence 48.
I'll tell you what scares me if you tell me what scares you. Doug did not see this coming.

Fair enough. When I was twelve I was climbing a tree and I accidentally put my hand through a giant hornets' nest. They didn't like it. I got stung over a hundred times. They had to rush me to the hospital. I've been afraid of hornets ever since. Don't climb many trees either.
Everybody has fears. Now, what scares you?
Me. Pause.
You scare yourself?
Sometimes.
Why, what about yourself scares you?
I have bad thoughts.
About what?
People.
People in general or certain people?
Certain people.
Like who?
You. 49. Silence.
You have bad thoughts about me?
Why?
I just do.
Was there something I said or did that upset you?
(shakes her head) It's just the way you are...
How am I?
Facile.
Facile? (she nods yes) Do you even know what that means?

Easily comprehended. Often lacking sincerity or depth. You're smug, too. Want me to tell you what that means? Dead silence. Doug skewered by a ten-year-old. A boyish shyness emerges, a relic from his own youth.
Well, if, um, if I seemed `smug' or `facile' I want to -
Don't apologize.
Why?
You're a grown up, it's embarrassing.
Should we talk about school now? My grades are getting a lot better. Doug just stares at her.
Waiting until Lucy is out of earshot down the hall, Doug confers with Emily by the water cooler. He's sweating, shaken by the encounter.
Talked to a lot of ten-year-olds, I don't think I've ever felt like that before...
Like what?
Threatened.
I know a specialist, I'll call him in the morning.
What do I do with her in the meantime? Doug pauses, no idea, smiles an eerie smile.

Don't let her get in your head. Exits. His paranoia feeding Emily's. In the hush she hear that faint CYCLICAL SQUEAKING. Looks across the darkened office to her cubicle where Lucy is turning circles in he chair again. That face. That face. That face.
Tense dinner. Emily barely touching hers. Lucy, absently, but with an almost surgical precision, is CUTTING PEAS IN

head_text.subj: HALF ON HER PLATE AND EATING THEM ONE BY ONE OFF THE TIP

text: THE KNIFE. Weird. She stops, self-conscious, looks at Emi across the table.
Are you mad at me?
No. Just tired. 51.
Want me to brush your hair?
That's okay.
Are you sure?
Some other time.
It will make you feel better. I'll get the brush.

I said no, thank you. Lucy stares at Emily for a moment then sits again. And it strange, her posture seems subtly different, stiffer, bon as if all her muscles have drawn taut under her clothes. a voice at once innocent and menacing:
Doug said something, didn't he?
No. Doug? He says you're doing great. Tense silence.
What did he tell you?
Nothing. Lucy stares at her, seeing through the facade. Then, oddl bright, taking a bite of food:
You're funny.
EMILY SILHOUETTED in the doorway, keeping her distance as
Get some rest. 52. She starts to close the door.
You forgot to kiss me goodnight. A tense pause then Emily walks over and kisses her on the forehead.
Goodnight. Lucy clutches her wrist as she turns to go.
I love you. Emily, trapped, forces a tender smile.
I love you, too. Lucy's EYES GLEAM in the darkness. She turns onto her sid for sleep, but those eyes don't shut even after Emily has walked out and closed the door behind her.
Football highlights on a liquid plasma tv. Doug flipping through a DSM IV diagnostic manual. The phone RINGS. He picks up, distracted, scanning the DSM index.
Hello? A strange INTERMITTENT STATIC BUZZ on the line.
Hello...? BZZZZT. BZZZZT. BZZZZT. A telecommunications glitch.

Try again, sorry. He hangs up. Finds the chapter he's looking for. ANTI- SOCIAL PERSONALITY TYPE. But he hears it again now - BZZZZZZZZT BZZZZZZZZZT - louder, deeper - and realizes, i quiet terror, that it's coming from INSIDE HIS EAR. 53.
Doug opens the medicine cabinet and grabs a Q-tip. Wiggle it around in his ear and when he takes it out there's a

sitting on the cottony tip, scissoring its wings. Doug stares in disbelief. Mouth gaping. He throws the Q-tip in the toilet. Hits the flush lever. Watches the hornet spiral away. Gone. Stares at the empty bowl. Did I just imagine that? Shaken, he turns to the sink. Wedges his head under the t and runs water into his ear. Straightens and looks at himself in the mirror, toweling face, trying to impose rational thought on the situation. But as the water spills from his ear, down his neck, onto shirt, it brings with it - TWO MORE LIVE HORNETS, half drowned. With a yelp Doug swipes them from his shirt. Crushes them underfoot. Terrified, but clinging to rational thought a moment longer, he turns his head sideways to the mirror, parts his hair, and sees - ANOTHER HORNET crawl from the ear canal, followed by SIX

Rationality goes out the window. He flails at them with t towel. Swats them dead. Picks them up and drops them in t toilet. Studies the last one for a moment. Its little leg twitching. Drops it in. Flushes. A false respite. And a brief one. Because as the FLUSHING NOISE FADES he can hear an ominous DEEP BUZZING SOUND RIS It's coming from behind him. He turns to have a look. Nothing there. Bare wall. But it's strange: the BUZZING IS STILL BEHIND HIM. With dawning horror Doug turns and checks his back in the mirror, sees 54.

head_text.subj: HIS ENTIRE SHIRT BACK IS CRAWLING WITH HORNETS

text: Whimpering like a child, he undoes the buttons of his shi taking it off as delicately as possible. Slipping his arm gently from the sleeves. Holding it by the collar, he takes two quick steps and to it in the shower. Slams the glass door, seals the crack w towels. And watches the hornets fly around in the glass enclosure, BUZZING FURIOUSLY, bouncing off the glass. But as he backpedals he realizes the FURIOUS BUZZING is t close, too loud and too deep, to be coming from the showe over there. A sharp pain in his head confirms it. He GROA and brings a hand to his ear as something awful happens inside. The BUZZING in his right ear spreads to his left - LOUDER ANGRIER, its sources multiplying. Disoriented, he stumble backwards with an AGONIZING SCREAM. Catches sight of hims in the mirror, the terror of the moment on his face. This can't be happening. And now the nightmare takes a devilish turn. Looking at himself in the mirror, he sees -

head_text.subj: HORNETS START CRAWLING FROM HIS NOSE. FROM BETWEEN HIS LI
FROM UNDER HIS EYELIDS. THE BUZZING NOW UNBEARABLY LOUD.
ENTIRE SWARM RAGING INSIDE HIS SKULL, FIGHTING ITS WAY OU

text: Doug grabs his head in both hands and starts shaking it, trying to shake away the madness inside. But the hornets keep coming, COUGHED UP IN CLUMPS as he gasps for air. They're all over him, stinging his tongue, his eyes. He goes berserk and starts SMASHING HIS HEAD against the wall, the door, the edge of the sink, anything he can fin opening a deep gash in his forehead, smashing it harder a harder because the BUZZING WON'T STOP, cracking his skull SCREAMING HYSTERICALLY, pitching his head violently forwa and backwards like some demon-possessed heavy metal fanat It's a grotesque display that ends on a sickening note wh with one particularly violent head jerk, he snaps his own neck - CRACK!!! He sinks to the floor, head askew, astonished look on his face. And there he sits, paralyzed, eyes locked on the tv in th living room where football highlights play in silence. Fu conscious as the hornets fight their way back into his ea nose, and mouth - a pilgrimage back to the mind that bore them. 55.
Emily exits a counseling room. Says goodbye to a young
See you next week. - and comes down the hall toward the common area. A cowor stands from an adjacent cubicle. DENISE.
Seen Doug? He had an appointment with one of my kids this morning, never showed up.
Did you try calling him?
All I get is voicemail. Emily dials Doug on a fax/phone by the Xerox machine. On
Hey, this is Doug, here it comes - BEEP. She hangs up. A dark thought sends her toward the exit, calling back to Denise -
Cover my desk.
Emily knocking on the door of his Marina Del Rey townhous

Doug, it's me, it's Emily... No answer. She comes down the steps to his car, walks past it and th stops, noticing the window is open a crack. Slipping her hand inside, stretching, she extends one finger just far enough to push the button on the garage door remote clipp to the sunvisor. Up the drive, the door starts to open. 56.
A door in the first-floor hallway opens. Emily steps in.
Doug? No answer. She comes up the stairs into the LIVING ROOM. The tv is still on. Muted. Calls up the next flight of stairs.
Doug, you here? No reply. She goes up the stairs and down the hall and checks the BEDROOM. Empty. The bed unmade. It's when she turns from the room to go back downstairs that she sees h

head_text.subj: SLOUCHED DEAD AGAINST THE BATHROOM WALL, GUT BLOATED BY
DECOMPOSITION, FACE COVERED IN BLACKENED DAY-OLD BLOOD.

text: With stoic grief Emily walks down the cold, fluorescently corridor, intercepts a CORONER as he exits the exam room.
Dr Johannsen? He looks at her; pale, bespectacled, a bit standoffish.
You did the autopsy on Doug Winters?
(trying to remember) Winters -- oh, right, Douglas.
How did he die?
Family?
Friend. (preempting his reply) I know the rules -- please, he meant a lot to me. 57. Her face the proof. He indicates his adjoining office. Th go in.
He takes the autopsy report from a filing cabinet. Review his findings.
Compression fracture of the third and forth vertebrae. Severed his spinal cord. Actual cause of death was... suffocation.
You're saying he did that to himself?
It appears all his injuries were self- inflicted, yes.
Oh come on. He looked like he'd been beaten to death! Don't tell me he was some - some suicidal...
...I knew him! He was my best friend! She turns away crying.

Miss, I would never presume to know your friend better than you. But the injuries suggest he was trying to hurt himself. Unfortunately, he succeeded. I am sorry. Emily, composing herself, gives a quiet nod. She has no quarrel with this man.
Have you ever seen this before, somebody dying like this? The coroner files the report, world weary.
Truly, I am shocked every day by the violence people do to themselves.

DOUGLAS J. WINTERS etched in granite. A final prayer read by a PRIEST as he is laid to rest. 58. A breeze ruffles the clothes of the MOURNERS. Blows hair across Emily's haunted face. Lucy, at her side, sees her grief and reaches for her han Instinctively, Emily retracts it. Lucy registers the slig the wider implications. Emily watches the coffin descend. She weeps openly.

Emily, red-eyed, driving home, sees something in her peripheral vision that sends a chill through her. Lucy, gazing quietly out the passenger-side window, is SWINGING HER LEGS in that contented way children do. A sm but telling detail. Immediately HER LEGS STOP SWINGING, sensing Emily's stare. And with her head still turned awa
You think it's my fault, don't you? She turns to face Emily, who measures her words.

It was an accident. It was nobody's fault. Lucy holds her gaze. Then, as if to test her, reaches aga for Emily's hand. Trapped in the lie, Emily has to let he And as she drives on in that private hell, holding hands Lucy...
Emily, an emotional wreck, confides in Barron.
He was scared. He came out of that room with her, Mike, and he was scared. He said she threatened him.
Listen. You're still in shock. Let's
Diego said it was a man on the phone. You know who made that call. There was no one else in the house. (off his look) You think I don't know how crazy this sounds?! 59.
Look, I don't know, all I'm saying is a kid in his state of mind maybe isn't the most reliable witness.
Why is he in that state of mind? Why was Doug? Pull my phone records. See if she called him.

Emily. I already did. There were no calls from your house. Emily's argument collapses. She sits there for a moment, vexed, her intellect telling her one thing, her gut anoth She gets up to go. Pauses at the door.
Her mother and father, their bedroom door has these deadbolts on it, big ones, two of `em... Something came through that door and they didn't want it ever coming through there again.
Emily digs through her in-box, spilling things on the flo Finds the manila envelope Doug gave her. Rips it open. Dumps the contents into her hand.
Typed on the label: Sheridan, Marg. & Ed., Prelim. Psych Interviews.
ON A TELEVISION - Margaret Sheridan sits facing the camer responding to the questions of an unseen interviewer. Her haunted face and frank tone make the interview chilling.
And by forcing your daughter into the oven, can you tell me, what did you think the outcome would be?
You mean what were we doing it for?
Yes. 60.
To kill her.
Why?
God's will.
Pulling back, we see Emily alone in a dimmed conference r watching the tape.
And why was it God's will that you should kill your daughter? An eerie smile comes to Margaret's face.
Why is that funny, Margaret?
`Cause she's not my daughter.
You're her mother...?
I bore her, but she's not mine.
Help me understand. If you and Edward are Lucy's biological parents, how can she not be yours?
`Cause she's not Of us.
Not Of you? Margaret nods.
Who is she Of?
Not who, what.
What is she Of? 61.
Stop acting like you don't know what I'm talking about. Stares at him. Her eyes black and unblinking.
You think your daughter is the devil?
Not him himself, Of him, working in his name, in his honor.
Evil incarnate?
I don't care what you call it.
And why do you think that?
Not what I think it's what I know.
How do you know this? Could you give me an example? Margaret pauses. Seeming afraid for the first time. Some secrets perhaps best left untold.
She can make you see things. Visions.
Visions of what?
Hell. Damnation. Whatever you're afraid of.
I see. Any other `special abilities'?
People die around her, is that a special ability?
She kills people? 62.
Not by her hand, they just die. I had two brothers, Brent and Travis... Margaret's voice falters. Overcome by grief, she dissolve into tears. It's a side of her we've never seen. Human.
...and I mean they was healthy boys, healthy as can be. Eddie, three sisters. Soon as she was born they started dying.
You blame Lucy for their deaths? Margaret nods yes, wiping her eyes. Embarrassed. Unaccustomed to crying in front of strangers.
Why do you imagine you were spared?

I guess she couldn't get rid of us till she found somebody else. Now that she has, I don't imagine we're long for this world. CLOSE UP ON MARGARET - face streaked with tears, her pain deep and undeniable.
VIDEO OF EDWARD SHERIDAN in a violent rage. Pushing his chair back from the interview table, he stands, screaming through clenched teeth, his broken jaw wired shut:

head_text.subj: THE HELL DID I JUST SAY

text: Edward, please calm --

head_text.subj: DON'T KNOW WHAT YOU'RE TALKING ABOUT

text: A pair of orderlies rush in to restrain him. The CAMERA g knocked ajar in the struggle. The tape ends as they take Edward screaming to the floor.

head_text.subj: IT'S NOT CHILD KILLING IF SHE'S NOT A

text: And that's the interview. Emily stares at the BLANK BLUE SCREEN, transfixed, lowers her gaze to the table. There's a PHOTO tucked inside the psychiatric file. Edwar and Margaret in happier times - YOUNG BIBLE CAMP COUNSELO in T-shirts and hiking boots on a path through sunlit for Sweet. Innocent. Emily's age. The year they met perhaps. She holds it up to the newspaper mugshots for a before-an after comparison. The transformation of their faces is shocking. Emily sits frozen by the realization: Edward an Margaret Sheridan. Not criminals. Victims.
An old brick orphanage turned psychiatric hospital. Emily Volvo goes up the winding tree-lined drive.
Unfortunately Mrs Sheridan suffered a rather severe psychotic episode last night...
Emily and the CHIEF PSYCHIATRIST walk down a dark, institutional corridor.

...Woke up screaming, absolutely convinced she was on fire. She wasn't, of course, they managed to sedate her. But it's curious, she displays all the symptoms of a burn patient. Except the burns themselves... Margaret's door. Emily peers through a little square of reinforced glass. A padded cell. Margaret strapped to a bed. Writhing in pain. Laboring to breathe. Eyes swimming
In no condition for visitors as you can see. If you'd like, I could let you see Mr Sheridan? Emily hesitates, afraid of him.
Okay. She casts a departing glance through the window and shudd to see that Margaret's roaming eyes have locked on her in hollow stare. 64.
Restrained in a straitjacket, Edward is brought in by two orderlies who seat him at a table opposite Emily and then exit. Jaw wired, everything he says is spoken through clenched teeth.
I know I'm probably the last person you want to see right now, but you're... His stare unnerves her. She stops and collects herself.
You're the only one I can talk to. Lucy's been staying with me -
Who died? Emily falls silent. Her voice cracks with emotion.
A friend. Edward nods yup. Regards her in silence. Emily speaks, or tries to, just to fill that awful void.
I, ummm...
You're scared. Emily, skewered again, nods yes.
You oughta be. Dead silence. She meets his gaze. And there is eye contac true understanding.
You judged us before you ever walked in that house. Sat there in our living room tellin' us about our problems, how to be better parents - certain of everything and dead wrong about all of it.
Ask what you came to ask. After a moment: 65.
What is she? It's a question Edward has asked himself once or twice. H leans back in his chair and folds his arms with an almost casual air.

Can tell you what she's not. She not a daughter of mine. She's not a ten-year- old having trouble in school. She's not some innocent victim whose door you busted down and life you saved. And she's not going no place, lady, till she's good and done with you.
Done with me how?
However she wants. You think it's an accident her ending up with you? She saw you coming a mile away.
Why me? I don't have anything.

You have that you're good. Kindness. Decency. That's what she feeds on. Bleeds ya dry, moves onto the next. We were a big family, she went through us like a wrecking ball. And you know, every time something happened, every time, we had an excuse for why it wasn't her fault. Cuz it's easier to lie to yourself than think bad things about your baby girl. But finally we got to a point where me and Maggy looked at each other - (remembers so clearly) - where we looked at each other and we was out of lies, both of us. Most terrifying moment of our lives. And that's where you are now. Emily silently registering this truth.
I'll tell you this. She sees everything. And what she doesn't see she just sort of senses it, like when you call a friend and they pick up before it rings?

Only time you got the upper hand is when she's sleepin' but she almost never does. We checked on her every night for three months. Every twenty minutes, up and down those stairs. First time she slept was the night you kicked in my front door. After a moment:
What does she want?
To know... what your idea of hell is... and make you live there. Emily sits in haunted silence. Edward's features soften.
I'm not a hateful man. I look at you and I wish I could tell you you're through the worst of it. That it's gonna work out for you in the end. I wish I could.
What should I do? A pitying smile reveals Edward's wired teeth.
How strong's your faith?
NANCY, the bloated director from the custody panel, walki briskly down a corridor. Emily calls to her from behind, approaching.
Nancy...?
Emily, I heard about Doug. I'm so sorry.
Do you have a minute? Nancy glances at her watch, nods okay, a minute.
Emily and Nancy enter the lavish office. 67.
How's it working out with the Sheridan girl?
Actually, that's why I'm here. I appreciate what you did for me, Nancy, I really do, but I think it'd be best if she was placed in foster care.
She is. You're it.
I know, but it's not working out.
Playing mommy isn't the laugh-a-minute you were hoping, huh?
I suppose not. Nancy nods, not entirely surprised.
Sorry, you petitioned for custody, you got it. She's your responsibility.
Until when?
Till we find a suitable foster home.
How long is that going to take?
You're asking me questions you know the answer to. Three to six weeks. Surely you can manage that long.
I don't want her anymore. I'm done. That's it. Nancy grimaces. Scary lady.
Now you look. I put my reputation, quite possibly my career, on the line for you. Don't embarrass me. You make this work. 68.
How do I make it work if it's not working?
However! Find a way!
A CLERK stops in an aisle, hands Emily a DEADBOLT from a shelf.
That what you're looking for?
Thanks. He walks off. Emily weighs the deadbolt in hand. Puts it down and picks up the next larger size. Grabs a second on just to be safe. A third for good measure.

With urgency Emily removes all her backup files from the shelf in Lucy's room. Dropping them in banker's boxes. Stops on Diego's. Eyes his photo. Drops it in. Grabs the office phone, boxes it with the files.

Emily unplugs the phone in the kitchen. Unplugs the one b the sofa. Opens the closet and tosses the phones inside with the banker's boxes she put there. Closes the door. Locks it. Hides the key. Just then, a FLASHING RED LIGHT draws her gaze to the win
stopping at the end of the block. Emily crosses to the window, watching as

gets off and comes up the sidewalk toward the house. Sens Emily's stare, she stops and meets it. Waves, testing the waters. Emily waves back but it's a hollow gesture. Lucy' smile fades, knowing this as she continues toward the hou 69. In a sudden panic Emily goes into the kitchen, grabs one the knives. Eyes the blade, forced to contemplate the unthinkable - its use as a weapon, self-defense. She comes into the living room, holding it. Catches sight herself in the mirror. A jarring image: Sweet Emily Jennings with a butcher's knife in her hand. The sound of LUCY'S FOOTSTEPS on the front steps breaks t spell. Emily hides the knife behind the fish tank. No good, you see it through the glass. We hear LUCY'S KEY IN THE LOCK. Emily grabs the knife. It's in her hand as the door CLICK open, until the last second when she tosses it under a so pillow. Lucy enters. Shy. Innocent. A ten-year-old home from school.
Hi. Emily returns a plastic smile.
Hi.
You weren't there so I took the bus.
Sorry, work - lost track of time.

It's okay, I know how busy you are. Emily watches unnerved as Lucy crosses to the sofa, to th very pillow where she hid the butcher's knife, and sits d to untie her shoes. The point of the knife is almost touching her leg. If she moves at all, it will cut the sk
Doesn't matter anyway, the bus stops right at the end of the street. So I can always get home, whether you're there or not. 70.
Lucky. Lucy nods then pauses and looks at the pillow, or appears but she is actually looking at the end table.
Where's the phone?
Oh, it wasn't working... Lucy nods oh. Finishes untying her shoes then gets up and walks into the kitchen, checks the wall, turns to Emily.
Wow. That one, too. Emily, caught in a lie, says nothing.
Can I have a shower? We had gym today... Emily nods. Lucy heads into the bathroom. Pauses at the door, back turned.
Are they being nice to her?
Who?
My mother. She turns for Emily's reaction.
How - how would I know that?
I thought you said you were going to see her.
I never said that. Lucy frowns. A bewilderment that seems genuine.
Hm. I must have dreamt it. Goes into the bathroom. Closes the door. 71.
Ear pressed to the bathroom door, Emily listens to the RUNNING WATER: Lucy taking a shower. She goes to the closet, unlocks it. Grabs one of the phon
It sounds like EMILY'S VOICE is coming from the fridge un we sweep past it to see her crouching by a phone jack in corner. Whispering.

I don't care, Robin, anywhere. Just find somewhere that will take her. Tonight. I don't want this girl in my house. Emily unplugs the phone. And just then hears a SOFT BREAT behind her. Oh shit. Slowly turns. LUCY IN A BATH ROBE BEHIND HER. Hair dripping wet. A chilling stare. How much did she hea Lucy walks out. We hear her bedroom door close. Emily crouched in the corner, holding the phone, terrifie the thought of what's in store.

THE HEAD OF A TURNING SCREW - Emily installing a DEADBOLT her door in the middle of the night. It's the third lock, the other two already in place. Hand trembling, she lines up the last screw. It slips from her fingers. ROLLS UNDER THE DOOR. She cracks opens the door. Reaches to grab it and lets ou SHRIEK, recoiling -
standing just outside her door.

head_text.subj: LUCY, IN PAJAMAS, HOLDING THE SCREW

text: She hands it back to Emily, making no overt acknowledgeme of it.

Good night. 72. She walks down the hallway to her bedroom. As soon as Lucy's door closes, Emily closes hers and goes back to work, doublespeed. Winds that last screw into the wood and then slides-to the heavy bolts. CLUNK. CLUNK. CLUNK. Scooting backwards, she sits against the bed, wide-eyed w terror, screwdriver clutched in her fist like a stabbing weapon.

A bell TOLLS in a steeple. Down below, Emily is going against the tide, walking up t steps past CHURCHGOERS who are coming down after morning mass. Halfway up, she runs into Mike Barron and his wife son. It's awkward, more for her than him.
Emily...?
Mike.
Sitting on a bench in a park that occupies the shadow of old stone church, Emily and Mike talk privately. His wife pushing his young son on a playground swing.
`No such thing as a bad kid, only bad parents.' I always believed that. It's a lie. Her parents aren't crazy.
You wanna end up where they did keep talking like this. (off her look) I'm not judging you. You're grieving for Doug and you're still confused about what Diego did.
Aren't you?
Diego grew up in a bad home, he saw violence and he repeated it, that's the cycle, you know that better than anyone. 73.
Why did she lie about calling him?

`Cause she's a liar, that doesn't mean she made him do it. Look, let me tell you what Lucy is. Lucy is a damaged child, a deceitful child, a manipulative child. But a damaged, deceitful, manipulative child is not a demon. Ask my brother-in-law, he's got a couple of `em. Barron stands from the bench.
Mike, you know I'm not crazy. Don't run away from something just because it scares you. His concern edges toward sadness. He indicates the church
I stopped you on the steps. I think maybe you oughta go all the way in. Walks off to rejoin his wife and son. Emily alone on a be in the shadow of a church.

The circle of abused children. Lucy among them, a happy participant. Nancy filling in for Doug. It's EMILY'S POV - as she spies on Lucy through the windo second-guessing herself for a moment. Session over, Nancy dismisses the group with a smile and theatrical applause. Emily watches Lucy cross the room. At the coat rack, she whispers something to another girl. The veil of Lucy's ha partially obscures her profile, but through that veil Emi sees something chilling. For a moment, a moment so fleeti it might just be a trick of the eyes -

head_text.subj: LUCY'S LIPS APPEAR THICKER, MORE MASCULINE, SPEAKING CAUS
WORDS THAT HOLD THE OTHER GIRL CAPTIVE.

text: Emily draws a sharp inward breath. Lucy, feeling Emily's stare now, turns to meet it. Her SWEET INNOCENT GIRL LIPS widening into a smile. 74. But Emily knows what she saw. She throws open the door an rushes in.
Grabs Lucy by the arm and yanks her bodily from the room. This, to the amazement of Nancy, the other children -
- and to the shock of the other PARENTS waiting outside. Nancy comes after her in a fury. Runs her down. Erupts.
Who do you think you are barging in there like that?!
I don't want her in group anymore, I don't want her around the other kids.
Well that's not your decision, is it?! Emily opens her mouth to reply, but Lucy beats her to the punch.
It's okay, Nancy, Emily's been under a lot of stress lately, but she's really nice to me and I hope I can stay with her a really long time. Nancy, disarmed by the glowing praise, turns back to Emil
We'll talk about this later. Storms off.
See you next week, Nancy. Nancy doesn't hear, busily reassuring parents, damage control. Emily and Lucy arrive at the elevator. Emily hit the button.
You're never going back there.
Why, Emily? 75. Emily says nothing. Lucy keeps asking the same question, the exact same intonation, as Emily ignores her:
Why, Emily? Why, Emily? Why, Emily? DING. The doors open.
Emily and Lucy step in. The door closes. Lucy continuing her verbal assault as they start to descend:
Why, Emily? Why, Emily? Suddenly the ELEVATOR LURCHES TO A VIOLENT STOP. It buckl Emily's knees. She is terrified, practically hyperventilating.
W-w-what's happening - ?! Lucy has gotten her attention.
Can I go back to group next week?
You're never going back there! Lucy looks at her as one regards a small dumb animal. The looks up at the ceiling.
Are you sure? Horror as Emily realizes what she's thinking. We hear the first CABLE SNAP above them. In the CREAKING HUSH that

No... The second CABLE SNAPS. The elevator goes into a HELLISH FREE FALL. The acceleration is dizzying. Emily clutches the rail with both hands, SCREAMING as the elevator goes cannonballing down the shaft. Lucy indiffer as they plummet toward certain death. 76. The floor indicator light races toward L, the car shudder violently, the noise deafening. It's a horrible way to di Emily closes her eyes in anticipation of impact. And in t sudden BLACKNESS there's no noise at all. Just a soft,

A breathless pause then Emily opens her eyes. And sees th elevator is no longer falling. Never was. The doors glide open to the first floor lobby. Lucy gives her a quiet look and strolls out. A businessma steps into the elevator, watching bewildered as Emily releases her white-knuckled grip on the railing and stagg out, so badly shaken she can barely stand...
Fish swim languidly in the tank. It's after midnight. We' looking down the darkened hall at Emily's closed bedroom door.
Emily, in a coat and shoes, packing a suitcase. Snaps it quietly shut. Looks over at the barricaded door. Draws a tense breath.

From down the hall we hear the DEADBOLTS SLIDE QUIETLY OP The door opens a crack. EMILY'S TERRIFIED FACE peers out. Making sure the hall is empty. She steps out, suitcase in hand. Tiptoes down the hall. Quietly as possible as she comes p Lucy's door. It's open a crack. The room pitch black inside. Emily steps closer, breath held. Peers in through the little crack. Sees - LUCY ASLEEP IN BED. But suddenly her EYES SNAP OPEN. Her face horizontal on t pillow.
I can see you. 77. Emily backs away. Goes quickly to the front door.
Emily throws the suitcase in the trunk. Slams it shut. Comes around to the driver's side door. Jumps in. Closes the door. And gets the scare of her life.

head_text.subj: LUCY IS SITTING IN THE PASSENGER SEAT

text: Emily recoils with a SCREAM, throwing her body against th window behind her. Lucy sits there, silent, betrayed. It's too much for Emily. She breaks down. Buries her face in her hands and sobs. Lucy, after a moment, takes a brush from Emily's bag and starts lovingly brushing her hair. Emily slowly lifts her head, resigning herself to this la horror. She sits zombie-like behind the wheel, tears streaming as Lucy tugs gently at the snarls, playing momm
Don't be sad. This is your new beginning.
