Unopened mail and new case files piling up. Emily looks terrible, phone to ear, getting SCREAMED at, sworn at, interrupted every time she tries to speak.

Mrs Lynch, I told you - will you let - that's not what I said - no, I did not - you never sent me the - Mrs Lynch - will you let me respond? - will you let me - Mrs Lynch - will you let - Emily can't take it anymore. She unloads.

head_text.subj: SHUT THE FUCK UP YOU MISERABLE MISERABLE
WOMAN BEFORE I GET IN MY CAR AND COME
OVER THERE AND BEAT YOUR ASS LIKE YOU
THINK ABOUT THAT NEXT TIME YOU CALL AND

text: Slams the phone down. Sits there looking rather dazed. Wayne arrives, dazed in a different way, having overheard 78.
Um, so, I notice you haven't taken any personal days. Come on, you look like crap, go home. Emily levels a withering stare.
I don't want to go home.
Emily knocking on a door in an outside hallway. It opens. It's the girl from the bar. BECCA. The friend. Not expecting her.
Emily...
Emily, disheveled, five days without sleep, doing her bes appear rational.
I know I haven't been a great friend lately, but... do you think maybe I could crash here for a couple of nights?
Sure, when?
Tonight and tomorrow. Becca draws air through her teeth, pained by her predicam

Em, any other weekend you know I'd say yes, but I just met this guy and he's coming over tonight like for the night and it might be, you know, kinda weird. Emily nods. And there's nothing more to be said.

Stormy night. Heavy rain. High winds. The trees, thrashin outside the window, backlit by a streetlight, cast OMINOU SHADOWS on the walls of the bedroom. Emily huddles in the corner, wrapped in a blanket, clutch the screwdriver. 79. There is a KNOCK on the bedroom door. Emily's EYES JERK W OPEN. She looks at the door, but doesn't answer. After a moment, Lucy's voice, innocent, afraid -
Emily...? Can I come in? I'm scared... Emily says nothing. Heart racing. There's another KNOCK. little louder.
Emily? Please? I know you're in there, please...? Emily says nothing. Lucy starts pounding on the door.

Please, Emily... SILENCE. Emily listening, barely breathing. Is that it? Is she gon And then suddenly - WHAM! - WHAM! - WHAM! - the pounding turns VIOLENT, practically shaking the door off its hinge Far too violent for a little girl. Emily wedges herself into the corner, absolutely petrifie There is something very strong and very angry on the othe side of that door, SHRIEKING in the voice of a child -

WHAM - WHAM - WHAM - WHAM - WHAM - WHAM! The door getting absolutely pummeled, looking like it might splinter from force. And it's so intense that it's almost surreal what Emily is seeing. Lucy's voice eerily monotone, the words coming inhumanly fast like some auctioneer from hell -

Let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in, let me in... 80. Relentless. Tormenting Emily. Until she can't take it anymore. And she SCREAMS as loud as she can, half cursing half begging, the veins standing out in her neck -

And the POUNDING STOPS DEAD. All we hear is the rain drumming on the roof. And Emily's QUICK TERRIFIED BREATHS she stares at the door wondering what's next. But there's nothing. Just the shadows dancing on the wall It appears the nightmare is over for now. But not quite. A sudden CLUNK in the closet makes her jump. Her head sna around - what was that? She just stares, unable to breath because whatever she just heard is INSIDE HER ROOM! White-knuckled grip on that screwdriver, Emily stands up comes slowly over to the CLOSET DOOR. Raises the screwdriver. Ready to stab. Takes hold of the door handle. Slowly turns it. Opens the door. PITCH BLACK inside. A tense pause as she stares into that blackness, then rea a hand into the closet, feeling around for the pull-strin Finds it. Gives it a tug. And there, right in front of he is a vision of unspeakable horror:

Twitching spasmodically in a hospital gown. HIDEOUSLY BURNED. She comes at Emily arms flailing, clumsy with rage and dementia. Emily leaps aside and Margaret goes careening i the furniture, howling and spinning like some crazed Whir Dervish. Emily scrambles over the bed. Reaches the door. Fumbles a the deadbolt. Here comes Margaret. At the last second Emi gets the door open. Runs out. 81.
Tears a path down the dark hallway. Margaret right behind her, hideous, reeling, hitting the walls with her flailin arms. Emily throws open the front door.

Dashes from the house into the abandoned street. Running the rain. Margaret comes crashing out of the house, chasi her down the middle of the street. Emily sees a city bus parked up ahead. Makes a run for it
A metro transit bus idling along the curb. The DRIVER wit his feet up between shifts, reading a porno mag. Emily co running up to the door. Pounds frantically on the glass.
Help me! Please! The driver meets eyes with her through the door. Keeps reading. Unimpressed. More pounding from Emily.
Let me on! The driver points to the sign above the door: OUT OF SERV Keeps reading. Emily near hysterics at this point. Margar closing in fast.
She's coming! Please! The driver sighs, weighing his obligations. Emily spins, back to the door. Margaret nearly upon her, ten feet away five, four...
The driver opens the door. Emily dives backwards onto the bus, the door snapping closed in front of her just as Margaret lunges for her throat.
Drive!
There's nobody out there. 82.

There - is - nobody - out - there! It sinks in the second time. Emily scans the sidewalk, th darkened streets outside the bus. Margaret is gone. Was never there. The driver opens the door, nods to her - out

With a hydraulic HISS the bus releases its brakes and die off down the empty street. Emily stands alone. Rain-soake Shivering. Staring at her house down the block. The SILHOUETTE OF A CHILD in the window.
Wayne and his BOYFRIEND shake rain off an umbrella as the cross the darkened office.
(re: the office space) No, I like it. It's like those things they put baby cows in to make veal - The boyfriend slows as they go past a cubicle. Saw someth weird.
What? He points. Freaked. Wayne comes over, pokes his head in a cubicle.
head down on her desk, rain-soaked, sleeping in her chair
Em...? No reply. Wayne's face darkens. Is she dead? He comes over, puts his hand on her shoulder.
Emily...? She awakens with a jolt. Expecting to see Margaret. She looks terrible. 83.
Jesus - are you okay?
I... I had some things to catch up on... She fumbles unconvincingly at some loose paperwork.
You look like shit, you need to see a doctor.
I saw a doctor.
What did they say?

They said mind your own fucking business! Shocked by the outburst, by her general appearance, he wa away, muttering to his boyfriend. Emily puts her head in hands, pressing down at her temples. Wayne steps into his office in the b.g. and grabs something then they exit. And the office is quiet again. Emily closes her eyes. Jus then, she hears - A faint CYCLICAL SQUEAKING NOISE in the cubicle right nex hers. Goes rigid. Recognizes the sound. Calls over the partition without moving.

Wayne...? No reply, but the SQUEAKING CONTINUES. Rising slowly from her seat, scared as hell, she leans over her desk and pee over the partition into the adjacent cubicle. It's empty. But the OFFICE CHAIR IS TURNING as if someone were just playing there. Emily steps slowly back. And now hears the same CYCLICAL SQUEAKING behind her. The opposite row. She spins.

Walks slowly from her cubicle. Comes along the row of darkened cubicles, following the sound to its source. Thi is the one. She looks in. 84. Empty cubicle. TURNING CHAIR. Emily backs away. Terrified. The chair winding slowly to stop. Suddenly, behind her, at the far end of the office, a different NOISE splits the silence. Emily turns and stare toward the sound. The XEROX MACHINE. Someone is using it.

Hello...? No answer. Emily comes slowly down the aisle to the partitioned workstation. A torturous walk set to the RHYTHMIC CADENCE the photocopier, the HARSH GREEN LIGHT SWEEPING ACROSS TH CEILING ABOVE IT, again and again and again... And then it stops, ejecting one final page as Emily enter the workstation. And sees there's no one there. She stares at the idle machine for a moment, then at the STACK OF COPIES lying upsidedown in the tray. She comes over, picks them up. Turns them over. The first page is a photocopy of a PAIR OF HANDS PRESSED AGAINST THE COPYING GLASS. Emily stares, haunted. Tense breath. Continues through th stack. Successive pages show the same two hands, but leaning for into the inky blackness between them is a FACE, its featu resolving into murky focus as it approaches the glass. Th last page is a horrific image. A man screaming in such terror that his face appears almost deformed. It's DOUG. The night of his death. Like a snapshot from h bathroom mirror. Emily shudders, the stack of pages tumbling to the floor. Runs out. And we see the photocopies, lying on the floor, are totally BLANK...
Emily, leaving, rushes down a corridor toward the lobby. Tense. Head on a swivel. Hears MORE SQUEAKING behind her. Spins.

head_text.subj: A NIGHT JANITOR WHEELING A MOP BUCKET

text: She walks on. Turns the corner and RUNS INTO SOMEONE UNEXPECTED. Jumps back with a SHRIEK before she realizes it is.
Robin... A ponytailed woman in her mid-forties, the child placemen specialist Emily called from home.
What are you doing here so late? I tried calling you. I found someone to take Lucy.
You did?
Anaheim couple. They've helped us out before. She shows Emily a custody form with an attached photo: A KIND HUSBAND AND WIFE WITH TWO YOUNG CHILDREN. Emily's face darkens.
(under her breath) Oh God...

What's the matter? Emily stares at the unsuspecting family. Lucy's next victims. She fends off a wave of emotion as the full horr of her predicament hits her. Then, matter-of-factly, faci that fear head-on:
I can't. I'm keeping her. As Emily walks off, ripping the custody form to shreds, R utterly confused...
Emily sits opposite Edward Sheridan in the visiting room, odd sense of camaraderie between them. 86.
If I get rid of her, if I put her into the system...
She starts all over again somewhere else. Can't let her stay, can't let her go. That leaves you with one option. Eye contact. Emily looks away, shakes her head.
I can't, Edward, I --
You have to. You have to find the strength. Don't you understand? That's why she's doing this. To test you. Test your faith.
I don't have any faith.
How `bout anger. Got some of that? Emily lowers her gaze to the table.
How... how do I...?
Kill her? In her sleep, assuming you can...

Tell you what I'd do different. Count myself dead at the outset. Accept that going in and use it to my advantage. That's the one thing I don't think she'd see coming, someone giving up their own life to take hers. As Emily registers this...
Middle of the night, the living room is lit by the eerie of the fish tank. The filter humming. The fish swimming languidly. Suddenly they DISPERSE, spooked by something outside the tank. 87.

The bureau has been pushed in front of the deadbolted doo form a barricade. Emily lies in a fetal position on her b exhausted but unable to sleep. She tenses at the sound of a MUFFLED MALE VOICE in the ot room. Comes over to the door, trying to listen. Thinks sh recognizes it.
(calls through door) Mike...? No reply. A moment of indecision then Emily tightens her grip on th screwdriver and quietly slides open the deadbolts.
She comes slowly down the hall, following the VOICE to it source, stops in the living room doorway, haunted...
Edward's psych interview playing to the empty room. He's straightjacketed, sedated. Talking directly to the camera
Where is she now? Some family somewhere?
Why does that concern you, Edward?

`Cause you have to warn them. Emily turns off the tv. IMMEDIATELY IT SWITCHES ITSELF BA ON. Emily freezes, realizing the room is not empty. Turning, she sees Lucy sitting in the shadows holding the remote. Lucy mutes the sound and returns Emily's stare, thoughtful, almost empathetic.

I like it here. I like you. You want me to like you, don't you? Emily nods. The room bathed in the tv's flickering blue light. Lucy is quiet for a moment. Then, in her innocentl menacing voice, explains the rules: 88.

You have to do what I say. If I say I want to go to group, you have to do it. If I say I want a new dress, you have to do it. If I say I want ice cream every day after school, you have to do it. Okay? Emily gives a haunted nod, remembering: A FLASHCUT of Lucy sitting between Edward and Margaret at Child Services meeting, new dress, ribbon in her hair, licking her ice cream with a wicked little smile.
Lucy stares coldly at the television: Margaret speaking w the sound off.

They did what I said for a while and then they stopped and started with the secrets. But they weren't really secrets I guess... (looks at Emily) ...because I always knew what they were thinking. She holds Emily's gaze then looks back at the tv. Margare image reflected in the pupils of her eerie unblinking eye
Margaret, straps unbuckled, sits on the bed beside a YOUN NURSE who checks her temperature. Done, the Nurse heads o
Don't leave me. Terror in Margaret's voice.

It's okay, Maggie. I'll check on you later. The Nurse exits. Locks the door. CLICK-KA-THUNK. The sound of doom to Margaret. She stands up, looking around, trembling at what's to com Her footsteps sound oddly HOLLOW, METALLIC on the floor. 89. MARGARET'S POV - surveying the room, we see what Margaret hell looks like. It's not a room she's living in...

With dark scorched metal walls. A bolted-down bed to one side, perfectly white, like a practical joke. We can hear the low HISS of it filling with gas. The fain POOF as it ignites beneath her. The first SHIMMERING WAVE OF HEAT rising up, singeing her hair. Margaret runs screaming to the door, claws at the pane of glass like a madwoman. But there is no escape from the he of her own mind. The YOUNG NURSE'S FACE APPEARS there in window, shocked by Margaret's insane rantings.

Edward, dinner tray in hand, going through the cafeteria with other INSTITUTIONAL PATIENTS. He sits down at a table and starts eating, quiet, lost in thoughts. Takes another mouthful of food and suddenly sto chewing, noticing something very strange:

head_text.subj: A BALD, MORBIDLY OBESE INMATE SITTING DIRECTLY ACROSS THE
WITH AN ALMOST SURGICAL PRECISON, EATING THEM ONE BY ONE

text: He lifts his gaze to Edward. Smiles a knowing, taunting smile. Then his WIDE WET MOUTH speaks in a little girl's

I'm happy you're getting the help you need, daddy. Edward goes berserk. Launches himself across the table at the guy, stabbing him in the neck with his fork. Vicious attack. Unprovoked as far as anyone else is concerned. A guard rushes over. Edward turns on him, maniacal. THE GUARD SHOOTS HIM DEAD. As blood pools around Edward's body, some LUNATIC who witnessed the event starts to applaud. Others join in. It the most excitement they've seen all year. And as the applause spreads through the entire cafeteria... 90.
Emily comes down the steps, past the morning paper on the walkway. Stops dead in her tracks. Stunned. Comes back an picks it up.

head_text.subj: A SMALL PHOTO OF EDWARD ON THE FRONT PAGE WITH A HEADLINE

text: At the bus stop at the end of the street, Lucy mingles happily with other CHILDREN. She meets Emily's gaze down length of the sidewalk. Smiles and waves goodbye as she g on the school bus.
Emily drops the newspaper on Barron's desk. The headline about Edward speaks for itself.
I know... It's a different Mike Barron than last we saw. Gone is th quiet assurance. Whatever happened rocked him to the core He closes the door for privacy.

There's something I want you to hear. Came in at two o'clock last night. You might wanna sit. Emily sits. Barron cues a voicemail message on his phone, plays it over the speaker. After a BEEP we hear it. A SINISTER MALE VOICE, guttural, taunting, the voice of a
(mocking his earlier line) `It's hard sometimes to tell the truth, but I know you will `cause you're a good little girl...'

Twenty years in the trenches, can't make Lieutenant? Hurts, doesn't it? Shakes your faith sometimes. You know why they keep passing you over? Do you, Michael? `Cause you're soft. Soft, soft, soft... DELIRIOUS LAUGHTER followed by a CLICK and a DIAL TONE. Emily's mouth gapes. After a moment: 91.

You're right. She called Doug. Took me an extra couple of days to get your cell phone records. That's what she's been using. Grim pause. Emily digs through her bag. Reaches the botto No cell phone. Staring into the bag, voice wavering with
She's taking me apart, Mike. She loses it for a second. Barron sits in front of her on the edge of the desk.
I'm gonna help you get to the bottom of this.
(re: Edward's photo) He told me I have to kill her. Barron registers that in silence. Stuns her, and himself, what he says next.
I'll help you. Emily looks at him. Disbelief.
Whatever it takes. She hugs him. A godsend.
I'm gonna put Beth and Tim in a hotel. Keep her at the house.
Emily buttoning her shirt after an exam.
Physically you're fine. How's the stress?
I'm not sleeping, I was hoping you could give me something. 92. The doctor writes on her prescription pad.
Take one of these, you'll sleep. Emily watches the pen scribble.
A prescription pill bottle on the passenger seat. Emily, driving home, glances at it with apprehension.
A high-rise hotel in downtown Los Angeles.
Barron, saying goodbye to his WIFE and SON, sets down the overnight bags they've packed.
Why won't you tell me what's going on?
Because I can't. Kisses her. Turns to his son.
Take care of your mom. Musses the boy's hair and leaves.
Barron strides down the corridor, his face reflecting the grim task ahead.

His footsteps echo in the parking structure as he walks a a row of parked cars. A faint JANGLING SOUND stops him dead in his tracks. He turns and scans the garage behind him. It's quiet, eerily still. He continues onward, but hears the faint JANGLING SOUND a a moment later. Spins, trying to place it. There it is again. Closer this time. Something moving, hiding, behind the rows of cars over there. 93. He bends, trying to get a look under the cars. Can't see anything. Unnerved, he moves on, clicks the button on his keychain remote. The lights flash on his car fifty yards away. But as he continues toward it they reveal themselves, trodding into view from between the cars, CHOKE-CHAIN COL JANGLING around their necks...

Battle-scarred. Vicious. The dogs from Diego's house. The sit down right in front of Barron's car. It's a surreal moment, a trio of attack dogs sitting at quiet attention, square-jawwed, black-eyed, the kinetic calm before a pred strikes. Barron draws his gun. Fires a warning shot over their hea

Deafeningly loud, it echoes through the garage like a thunderclap. But the dogs don't move, just sit there staring. Barron lowers his gun. It's time to get the hell out of here. He backpedals, making no sudden movements, gun stil trained on the dogs. They watch him, eyes livening with excitement, one of the back legs twitching in anticipation. Barron quickens his step and that's their cue.

head_text.subj: ALL AT ONCE, WITH EXPLOSIVE SPEED, THE DOGS SPRING INTO
MOTION, VICIOUS AND MUSCLED AND SMELLING BLOOD.

text: Barron fires an errant shot and takes off running. But he can't match their pace, the deadly trio race along the ro police cruisers, closing the gap with ease. At the last second Barron jumps the partition. The pit bu crash skull-first into the concrete, but continue their pursuit unfazed as Barron takes off up the adjoining ramp He jumps up onto the row of cars and runs across the hood denting the metal. The dogs jump up behind him, relentles in their pursuit. Jaws snapping at his heels, Barron takes to the car roofs the pitbulls leaping from car to car behind him. 94. He looks back just in time to see the dogs launch themsel They hit him at chest height, sinking teeth in his flesh. Stumbling forward, struggling to keep their jaws from his throat, Barron doesn't see what's coming. The last car. T edge of the parking garage. He's over the edge before he even understands, flailing h arms for a handhold that doesn't exist. The ground, far below, flies up at him in a rush of acceleration. We hear a sickening THUD and find Barron lying face down the pavement below, blood pooling around him. Clinging to life, he opens his eyes and sees the TRIO OF PIT BULLS SITTING OBEDIENTLY BESIDE HIM, unharmed, watching. But from a distance we see there is only Barron. Dying al between the parked cars. No dogs anywhere in sight.
Emily opens the front door, peers in, trying not to make sound.

Lucy...? No reply. She enters. Sees - THE CLOSET DOOR IS OPEN. She comes closer. EMPTY BANKER BOXES strewn in the hall. SCATTERED PAGES. At the far end, the light is on in Lucy's bedroom. The do open a crack. A shaft of light spilling out into the darkened hallway. Emily comes down the hallway past SCATTERED FILE PAGES. Preliminary reports. Medical records. Personality profiles... She opens the door to Lucy's room.
Freezes in the doorway, shocked by what lies before her.

Oh my God... 95. Black eyes. Bloody noses. Bruises. Cuts. Burns. PHOTOS OF ABUSED CHILDREN COVER THE ENTIRE FLOOR. A collage of misery. Lucy is nowhere to be seen. Emily comes in and starts quickly picking them up. Tucked between the file cabinet and the wall is a CORKBOA Emily pulls it out. It's covered with PHOTOS FROM WORK. COWORKERS. HER KIDS. Two of the photos are turned around. She flips them over in rapid succession. Diego. Doug. She rips all the photos from the board. Photos bunched in her hands, she heads for the door, but hears something that stops her in her tracks - A strange INTERMITTENT BUZZING NOISE It lasts two seconds and stops. She turns around, scans t room. Puts down the stack of photos. There it is again: BZZZZZZZZZZZT. BZZZZZZZZZZZZT. Sounds like a housefly trapped against a window, but it's bigger, angrier, and appears to be coming from the
at the foot of Lucy's bed. Emily crosses to it. The BUZZI STOPS. She bends. Takes hold of a corner. Peels it slowly back to reveal
Weird. Nothing there.
Emily straightens, turns. It's coming from the

As she approaches it the BUZZING INTENSIFIES, louder, mor agitated. Pauses as she gets there, terrified of what she might fin the bed BUZZING FURIOUSLY FROM WITHIN. Something is trapp under those blankets, waiting for release. Emily extends a trembling hand, takes hold of the blanket and, slowly, rigid with fear, peels them back to reveal 96.

Impossible, because the BUZZING IS LOUDER THAN EVER. With a tense swallow Emily realizes it's coming from lowe deeper within the bed, between the mattress and the box spring. She slips her fingers into the crack. And slowly lifts the mattress, the BUZZING GROWING FRIGHTENINGLY LOUD as its source is exposed, something hellish waiting for her as she cranes her neck and look t see what lies below -
Vibrating. BZZZZZZZZZT. BZZZZZZZZZZT. On the viewscreen:
She picks it up. Stares at it vibrating in her hand. Presses the TALK button. Brings it to her ear. The LOW STATIC of an open line. Then, a RASPY MALE VOICE:
Emily... Emily flinches.
Who is this...?
It's Wayne, Emily, I just got a call, Mike's dead... Emily, stunned, barely able to speak.
No... he's...
They don't know if he fell or what happened... Emily's phone hand drops to her side in shock. From down there, we hear Wayne's voice:
Emily? Emily, are you okay...? After a moment, she lifts it. 97.

I have to go. Hangs up. On the brink of emotional collapse. Her only confidante dead. Just then she hears BREATHING from behind the open door. Someone or something hiding in that dark corner over ther She crosses to it. Pulls back the door and there sits
quiet, innocent, chin on her knees.
What did you do to him? Lucy says nothing. Emily grabs her by the arm. Yanks her her feet.

head_text.subj: WHAT DID YOU DO TO HIM

text: After a moment:
He did it to himself. WHACK! Emily slaps her. Hard across the face. Knocks her to the floor. Lucy sits up, lip split. Tastes the blood with her tongue. Hint of a smile. The taste of victory.

Europa. Ganymede. Io. Callisto. The moons of Jupiter. We got back our astronomy tests today. It's there on the floor. A++ Well done, Lucy! There's a LOUD BEEP in the other room. Lucy gets up and walks out. Emily watches as Lucy goes into the kitchen. Takes a bag of popcorn from the microwave. Empties it int bowl. Sits down on the living room sofa and clicks on the remote, watching it like nothing ever happened. Emily wal over and pitches the tv onto the floor. The SCREEN SHATTE
Get out of my house. Lucy, unimpressed, expressionless, takes another handful popcorn. Chews it. CRUNCH. CRUNCH. CRUNCH. Emily swats the bowl from her hands. 98.

Flicking bits of popcorn off herself, Lucy stands up from sofa. Her face catches the light from the hallway. Emily shudders at the sight. Lucy's features look altered somehow, sharpened. It's subtle, but the overall effect is chilling. THE FACE OF A

head_text.subj: LITTLE GIRL LAID OVER THE MUSCULATURE OF SOMETHING MORE

text: Don't yell at me. My mom and dad used to yell at me. Emily backs away, mortified, takes off down the hall.

Rushes in. Slams the door. Bolts the deadbolts. CLUNK. CLUNK. CLUNK. Moment of panic. Will they hold? Slides her bureau in front of the door. Shoves her bed in front of the bureau just to be sure. In the silence we hear LUCY'S FOOTSTEPS coming down the h toward the door. Closer, closer... There's nothing else to block the door with. Emily backs away, trembling as LUCY'S FOOTSTEPS arrive at the door. A tense silence. The
Emily... I'm sorry... I didn't mean to... Emily grabs the screwdriver, clutches it in both hands.
Can I come in so we can talk and work it out? There's a GENTLE KNOCK on the door. Emily flinches, remembering last time.
Emily...?
Stay away from me! 99.
Don't be mad. I said I was sorry. I'll brush your hair for you.
Silence.

WHAM! The door shudders from a MAMMOTH IMPACT. Last time, it shook the door, this time it shakes the entire wall. Emily recoils, dropping the screwdriver. WHAM! CRACKS APPEAR in the door as it bows from the tremendous force. WHAM!! CRACKS FAN OUT into the plaster around the doorfra WHAM!! Half the SCREWS HOLDING THE HINGES fly from the wa WHAM!! The DEADBOLTS BENDING from the ungodly pummeling. WHAM!! The DEADBOLT SCREWS getting yanked from the wood. Emily frozen in terror, watching. Whatever's out there is coming in. WHAM!! One of the DOOR HINGES rips clean from the wall. WHAM!! The FIRST DEADBOLT comes flying off. WHAM!! The SECOND DOOR HINGE gone. WHAM!! ANOTHER DEADBOLT flies off. WHAM!! The DOOR SPLITS down the center. WHAM!! The THIRD DEADBOLT lands on the floor at Emily's f with a METAL THUD. A breathless silence. Then the DOOR RATTLES and drops loose from the frame with DEAD WOODEN CLUNK. Nothing holding it in place now except the bureau and the bed. And now they both start to SLIDE BACKWARDS as whatev is on the other side starts pushing its way in. 100. Emily topples a high bookcase against the door and pushes back with every ounce of strength she can muster, but it' use. The bureau overturns, CRASHES to the floor. Emily's bare feet slide backwards along with the bed. And then they stop. The barricade sufficiently breached. Emily, in her panic, makes a hasty decision. She hides un the bed. We HOLD LOW on the open door as LUCY'S FEET step into the room, the feet of a child, but the BREATHING we hear soun emphysemic and the VOICE is unquestionably male - harsh, guttural, taunting Emily as it comes for her:
Emily... Wide-eyed with terror under the bed, she watches those fe pick their way over the shattered remnants of the barrica
Emily... We need to learn healthier ways of resolving conflict, Emily. The feet step gingerly past the overturned bureau.
...Most families don't even know they have a problem... The feet stop at the SCREWDRIVER.

...until it's too late. A HAND reaches down and picks it up, a girl's hand, but t fingers as they wrap tightly around the handle look stron and sinewy. The feet stand motionless for a moment then turn and come toward the bed, stopping right in front of EMILY'S HORRIF FACE. A pause and then, still from Emily's POV, we see Lucy low herself onto her knees. WHAM!! - with shocking force that hand IMPALES THE
Another pause then both hands come into view, palms flat the hardwood, as she leans her head down. 101. Emily recoiling in anticipation as the face comes into vi
A little girl. With a little girl voice to match.
What are you doing, you silly pumpkinhead? Emily, hyperventilating, stares in shock. Lucy reaches he hand in. Emily backs away, wedges herself in the corner.
You don't want me to come under there and get you, do you? Emily, crying now, shakes her head. Lucy, almost sympathetic, frowns.
I'm going to count to three. One...
No...
Two... Two and a half...
Please...
Two and three quarters... Three... Lucy starts crawling under the bed.
Here I come. Emily tries to go backwards, but there's nowhere for her go. LUCY'S FACE SLIDING CLOSER LIKE THE HEAD OF A SNAKE. Trapped, Emily screams. 102.
Lucy stops crawling. Folds her arms, sets her chin on the Comfortable here under the bed. Delighting in the questio
What you wanted from your mother. I want you to love me.
Okay... okay, I will, I will, I promise. Lucy weighs Emily's surrender for a moment. Then, oddly
Come tuck me in.
Okay... I'll be right there.
You better come. Lucy slithers out and we see her feet scamper from the ro Emily puts her head down on the floor and cries, covering mouth with her hands so she won't make a sound.

A WHISTLING KETTLE on the stove. Emily, still in tears, takes it from the burner. Dumps SI SLEEPING PILLS from the prescription bottle. Crushes them with the blunt edge of a knife. Stirs them into a cup of Chamomile tea. She freezes at a NOISE behind her. Looks tensely over her shoulder. The fridge. She adds sugar, continues stirring.
We follow the TEA CUP, in Emily's hand, as she comes nervously down the hall to Lucy's room. We can see Lucy i there, waiting for her in bed. Emily, playing the part, dries her eyes and enters. 103.
Sits down on the bed, hands Lucy the tea.
Chamomile. Emily nods. The face of a loving mother. Lucy brings the cup to her lips, pauses.
Maybe you should have it, you look stressed.
I'll have one later. Lucy considers this, nods okay, takes a sip of tea. Emily picks up a brush and brushes Lucy's hair.
Tomorrow's our new beginning.
I'll be good.
I know. Lucy takes a few more sips and sets the tea cup on the bedside table. Emily, tucking her in, gives the cup a nervous glance. Did she drink enough?
Get some rest.
Say it.
I love you.
Forever and ever?

Forever and ever. Emily kisses her on the forehead. Lucy looks up at her an for a moment she's the little girl Emily met. Innocent, angelic, closing her eyes for sleep. They flutter open on last time. 104.
Where are you if I need you?
Right down the hall. Lucy's eyes shut. Emily, brushing her hair, staring at th HALF-FULL TEA CUP.
Lucy asleep in bed. Emily watches from the door, wary, expecting Lucy's eyes to snap open any second.

Sweetheart...? She doesn't move, dead to the world. Or is it a game? Emi closes the door. Leans against the wall, shaking, contemplating her next move. Wedges a chair under the door handle. Time of the essence
Junk-filled. The door lifts to reveal Emily, silhouetted, looking in. Amid the clutter is a lawnmower. Beside it, a big can of GASOLINE.

Emily stifling sobs as she douses the walls of the house. The hallway, the bathroom, the kitchen, all of it. TIP OF A MATCH strikes flint, ignites. Emily stares at it for a long moment. Lets it fall. FLAMES SCURRY in a shimmering blue-gold sheet across the floor. Climb the walls, the entire house ablaze in a matt of seconds. Emily sits and watches as the door to Lucy's bedroom is engulfed. It's an image straight from hell: A YOUNG WOMAN SITTING ON A SOFA IN A HOUSE OF FIRE. The fish, frantic in their tank, catch Emily's eye. She g over and grabs the tank. 105.
Smoke swirling past her, she exits the house, locking the front door behind her. She backs away and watches it burn holding her fish tank, the only thing she saved.

Billowing black smoke. The house fully engulfed as fire engines arriving on the scene, sirens wailing. Emily watching with neighbors on the sidewalk as the FIREFIGHTE uncoil their hoses. The window to Lucy's bedroom is a bright red square, an inferno. And as Emily stares at it, disbelieving what she done, the figure of a CHILD appears.
Her whole body ablaze. Horrific. She just stands there, arms at her sides, burning. Just now the FIRE MARSHALL crosses to the onlookers. Holl over the noise and commotion:
Everybody get out okay?! Emily wavers, not sure what to say. The Fire Marshall see her indecision.
This your house?! (she nods yes) Anybody else inside?! (off her hesitation) Ma'am...?! Emily opens her mouth to reply, but sees something behind that closes her throat.
standing on the sidewalk in her pajamas. Unscathed.

Anyone else inside?! Yes or no?! Emily, in shock, shakes her head no. The Fire Marshall rushes off, walkie-talkie squawking. Emily stands frozen Lucy comes through the crowd to her. More dismayed than angry. 106.
That was mean. She takes Emily's hand. Together they watch the house bur Firelight playing on their faces. The fish bouncing off t glass in the tank at Emily's feet.
The blue halflight before dawn. Emily and Lucy sit in the Volvo, eyeing the scorched remains of the house. The firecrew stowing equipment. Emily puts the car in drive.
The FISH FLOATING DEAD at the top of the tank in the back seat as Emily drives down the freeway at daybreak. Lucy gazing out dreamily at the sunrise.

Maybe we can find a hotel with a swimming pool. Emily says nothing. Lucy turns and looks at her, thoughtf almost empathetic. She draws up her knees and rests her c on top, levels an appraising stare at Emily like the one leveled at Doug.

It's sad, isn't it? How it gets passed on. How people do to their own kids what their parents did to them. That's why you got the job... Emily turns on the radio, full volume, trying to drown ou Lucy's voice. Lucy reaches over and turns it off. CLICK.
...To prove to yourself you're not like her, that you're not like your mother. Because that scares you. Scares you more than anything. Lucy, in mock sentiment, puts her hand on Emily's.

I love you... even if you don't love me. Emily looks at her, gutted. But defiant. Turning her gaze forward, she tightens her grip on the wheel and calmly, resolutely, JAMS THE GAS PEDAL TO THE FLOOR. The acceleration pitches Lucy backwards into her seat. She si up, eyes wide, didn't see this coming. A suicide run. 107.
What are you doing? Slow down. A tense smile from Lucy. The tables have turned.
Did you hear me? Emily stares dead ahead, red-lining the tachometer. Lucy flits her eyes skyward. IMMEDIATELY IT DARKENS AND STARTS RAIN. Emily turns on the wipers, speeds on, unfazed.

I said slow down! Emily ignores her, going eighty now, weaving through SLOW TRAFFIC THAT FLIES TOWARD THEM OUT OF THE GRAY HAZE. Lucy panicking, changes channels like a tv. Innocent child all a sudden.
Please, stop, Emily, I'll be good. Emily ignores her, beyond apology. And Lucy's face sharpe She points down the road.
Look out! Through the heavy rain we see -

head_text.subj: A TRACTOR-TRAILER RIG CRASH THROUGH THE DIVIDING MEDIAN A

text: Emily goes for the brake, but reconsiders, seeing the tru for what it is: a test of faith. She welcomes it. Tighten her grip on the wheel and goes full throttle again, right the truck. Lucy shrieks in terror.
What are you doing?!
It's not real.
Yes, it is!
Are you scared?! 108. Pedal to the floor. Inviting the head-on collision. You c see the BIG RIG DRIVER in the cab, wrestling frantically the steering wheel. Lucy bracing herself, screams -
Emily clenches her teeth in anticipation of impact, of de

head_text.subj: THE CHROME GRILLWORK OF THE TRUCK RUSHES TOWARD THEM IN T
FINAL MOMENT, THE AIR HORN DEAFENINGLY LOUD

text: But the impact never comes. In the blink of an eye the tr is gone. Open road in front of them. It's not raining. Never was. The wipers SQUEAKING on a dry windshield. Lucy sits in silence, her bag of tricks empty. Emily, triumphant, turns to her with a vindictive smile, the speedometer hitting a hundred.
She clutches Lucy's wrist.
Emily jerks the car off the road, crashing through the guardrail. Trees snapping in half across the hood as they careening through roadside woods and down a steep embankm
The car tears through a chainlink fence and leaps off the high embankment into the water.
Impacts and sinks with frightening speed. Water rushing i from all sides. Emily shackles Lucy with her arms as the water rises to cover their mouths.

They stare wide-eyed at one another through the water. Ha swirling around their faces as they sink to the bottom. LUCY'S LIPS CURL INTO THAT CREEPY MANNISH SMILE. As though she anticipated this. Or welcomes it. Or knows something Emily does not. And now Emily sees what Lucy se 109.

head_text.subj: A FIGURE SWIMMING DOWN TOWARD THEM THROUGH THE MURKY WATE

text: A HAND pries open the door and wrestles Lucy from Emily's grasp. Pulls her from the car, swimming to the surface wi her. Emily is left empty-handed, stunned, alone in her watery grave.

head_text.subj: SHE DROWNS IN STAGES, EACH ONE DIFFICULT TO WATCH, THE
DAWNING OF ACCEPTANCE, THE MUSCLES LOOSENING, ARMS FLOATI
LIMP, EYES FIXED IN A BLANK STARE.

text: And just when her death seems certain, a HAND grabs her b the shoulder and yanks her out the driver's side window..
Ambulances. Patrol cars. Paramedics. Onshore, drying off with a towel, talking to a uniformed officer is the PASSE who saved Lucy's life.

Right through the guardrail, never touched the brakes... Emily goes by on a gurney, semi-conscious, oxygen mask ov her face. Paramedics checking her vitals. Loaded into the ambulance, she meets the gaze of Lucy who being attended to by a female PARAMEDIC, who puts her arm around Lucy in a maternal gesture, shielding her from the sight of Emily as Emily did of the Sheridans.
Don't look at her, okay? Just don't even look. Lucy nods, the innocent victim. Clinging to her protector she watches the ambulance take Emily Jennings away.
of Lucy wrapped in a blanket sitting beside the female paramedic in an ambulance. Shivering. Wet-hair clinging t her face. Portrait of a child victim.

A remarkable story of survival this morning as a young girl is pulled from the Los Angeles reservoir in an accident police are calling suspicious... 110. INSTITUTIONAL PATIENTS watching tv in the psych hospital room. Slouched on the vinyl sofa, watching without comprehension, heavily sedated, Margaret Sheridan.
Emily talking agitatedly to a MAN IN A SUIT who is writin something and not paying attention to her. We only see he face at first.
Where is she? Where'd they put her? Foster care? Is she with a family? You have to let me talk to them... She snatches the pen from his hand.
Do you hear me?! He looks at her, quietly takes back his pen.
